All claims for expenses incurred in connection with the operation of the city's cemetery shall be filed with the city clerk treasurer, as provided in section 2-270, for approval or disapproval for payment by the mayor and city commissioners of the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska. 
(Ord. No. 2625-05, § 1, 1-17-05)  
Sec. 10-41. - Records. 
The cemetery advisory board shall keep its records in the office of the city clerk or at such other convenient place in the business section of said city as the cemetery advisory board shall determine as best suited for the economical administration of the affairs of the city cemetery. All its records, plats, papers, correspondence and documents shall be safely kept and preserved in said office. 
(Ord. No. 2625-05, § 1, 1-17-05)  
Sec. 10-42. - Rules, regulations. 
The cemetery advisory board shall have the power to adopt reasonable rules and regulations for the management of the cemetery, including the type of monuments which may be permitted or allowed. When said rules shall have been approved by the affirmative action of the mayor and city commissioners and three (3) copies thereof shall have been filed with the city clerk, said rules so adopted and filed shall become a part of this chapter the same as though copied at full length herein. 
(Ord. No. 2625-05, § 1, 1-17-05)  
Secs. 10-43—10-53. - Reserved  
ARTICLE III. - SUPERINTENDENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Appointive officers and employees generally, § 2-142 et seq. 
 
Sec. 10-54. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2625-05, § 2, adopted Jan. 17, 2005, repealed former section 10-54 in its entirety which pertained to appointment of the cemetery superintendent and derived from Ord. No. 2364, § 7, adopted Oct. 2, 1995.  
Sec. 10-55. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2364-95, § 13, adopted Oct. 2, 1995, repealed former section 10-55 in its entirety which pertained to the term of the cemetery superintendent and derived from the Code of 1938, Ch. 15, § 8.  
Sec. 10-56. - Compensation. 
The cemetery superintendent and other cemetery personnel shall receive compensation as provided by the City Employees' Step Pay Plan. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 15, § 8; Ord. No. 2364-95, § 8, 10-2-95)  
Sec. 10-57. - Duties generally. 
The duties of the cemetery superintendent shall be as outlined by the job description in the City Employees' Personnel Manual and as prescribed from time to time by the cemetery board. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 15, § 8; Ord. No. 2364-95, § 9, 10-2-95)  
Sec. 10-58. - Approval of claims. 
No claim for labor or material used in or about the cemetery shall be submitted to the mayor or city commissioners without the written approval of the cemetery superintendent, endorsed thereon to the effect that such labor was performed or that such materials were furnished. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 15, § 8; Ord. No. 2625-05, § 3, 1-17-05; Ord. No. 2760-09, § 1, 5-18-09)  
Sec. 10-59. - Turn over collected moneys. 
The superintendent shall promptly pay over all monies collected by him to the city clerk-treasurer and shall receive a receipt therefore. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 15, § 18; Ord. No. 2364-95, § 10, 10-2-95)  
Sec. 10-60. - Monthly report. 
(a)  On or before the last day of each calendar month, the superintendent shall file a written report with the city clerk-treasurer setting forth in detail the amount of money collected during the current month on account of lot sales, interments and other cemetery services and the amount of money expended by the cemetery board during the current month and for what purpose expended, identifying each item of expenditure by corresponding cemetery board claim number. 
(b)  The superintendent shall include in the monthly report a list of lots or burial spaces sold during that month or since the date of the last report, legally describing them, together with the name of the purchaser and the price received for each lot or space. 
(c)  The monthly report of the superintendent shall be referred to the city council for examination and the city council shall in its proceedings accept or reject said report. Failure or neglect on the part of the superintendent to file the monthly report for the space of ten (10) days from the end of each and every month shall automatically create a vacancy in his office, and, the mayor and council shall forthwith fill such vacancy. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 15, § 18; Ord. No. 2364-95, § 11, 10-2-95)  
Chapter 11 - CIVIL DEFENSE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— State of emergency curfew, § 24-132 et seq. 
State Law reference— State civil defense act, R.R.S. 1943, § 81-829.05 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 11-1. - Use of fire apparatus, personnel. 
The fire department shall move its fire and other emergency equipment and personnel outside the city and place them in immediate operation whenever ordered to do so by the state civil defense agency and to such place as it shall direct, either in the event of an emergency as defined by the state civil defense act, or in connection with any program for practice and training. 
The personnel of the fire department shall be considered as fully protected by the state workmen's compensation law in the course of any such movement and operation of the fire and other emergency equipment of the city. 
(Ord. No. 998, §§ 1, 2, 10-21-57)  
Sec. 11-2. - Emergency succession. 
The provisions of the state general emergency succession act are hereby invoked in this city and shall be binding upon the officers of the municipal government, including each member of the city council, the chief of police, the city clerk-treasurer, the chief of the fire department, the manager of the board of public works, the city physician, each member of the board of public works and the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 1564-77, § 1, 1-3-77) 
State Law reference— General emergency succession act, R.R.S. 1943, § 84-1101 et seq.  
Secs. 11-3—11-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL ORGANIZATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Local civil defense organization, R.R.S. 1943, § 81-829.18 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 11-18. - Created. 
There is hereby created a local organization for civil defense in accordance with the state civil defense plan and program. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 1, 1-5-42)  
Sec. 11-19. - Name. 
The local organization for civil defense shall be called Nebraska City Civil Defense Agency.  
Sec. 11-20. - Duties generally. 
The local organization for civil defense shall have all the powers and duties authorized and prescribed by state law as amended and such portions of this state law applicable to cities of the first class are hereby incorporated and made a part of this section as though spread at large herein and are hereby adopted by reference.  
Secs. 11-21—11-25. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Appointive officers and employees, § 2-142 et seq. 
State Law reference— Director of local civil defense organization, R.R.S. 1943, § 81-829.18. 
 
Sec. 11-26. - Office created. 
There is hereby created the office of director of the local organization for civil defense.  
Sec. 11-27. - Appointment. 
The director of the local organization for civil defense shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council.  
Sec. 11-28. - Term. 
The director of the local organization for civil defense shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and the city council.  
Sec. 11-29. - Powers, duties generally. 
The director of the local organization for civil defense shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, and operation of such local organization for civil defense, subject to the direction and control of the city council and such other duties as the state statutes may provide.  
Chapter 11½ - COURTS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 11½-1—11½-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COUNTY COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1563-77, §§ 1—5, adopted Jan. 3, 1977, did not specifically amend this Code, hence inclusion as Art. II, §§ 11½-16—11½-20, was at the editor's discretion. 
 
Sec. 11½-16. - County court; definition. 
The term "county court" as used in this Code shall be the District County Court, located in Nebraska City, the county seat of Otoe County, Nebraska, which shall be the court of exclusive original jurisdiction in any action based upon violations of the Code of Nebraska City and the ordinances of the City of Nebraska City. 
(Ord. No. 1563-77, § 1, 1-3-77)  
Sec. 11½-17. - Right to jury. 
Cases in the county court for violation of a city ordinance or the provisions of this Code shall be tried and determined by the county judge without the intervention of a jury. Cases of misdemeanor under the statutes of the state shall be tried by the county judge alone, unless the defendant demands a jury, which demand must be filed in writing and must be filed on or before answer day. If a jury is demanded the case shall be tried by a jury of six (6) competent persons, unless a smaller number is agreed to by the defendant, to be selected in the manner provided by law for selecting jurors in district courts; and the trial of such case before said county judge shall be continued in all respects not herein otherwise provided in like manner as in criminal cases before district court. Jurors in the county court shall receive the same fees as jurors in district courts, to be taxed as other costs are taxed in the case. 
(Ord. No. 1563-77, § 2, 1-3-77)  
Sec. 11½-18. - Appeals. 
In all cases before the county judge arising under the ordinances of the city, provisions of this Code or the laws of the state, an appeal from the decision of such county judge may be taken by the defendant to the district court or other court as provided by law, but no appeal shall be allowed unless the defendant shall, within ten (10) days thereafter, enter into a written recognizance with sufficient surety to be approved by the county judge in such sum as shall be fixed by him, but not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) in any case, conditioned for the defendant's appearance at the district court forthwith, if the said court be then in session, or on the first day of the next term thereof if said court be then in vacation, to answer the complaint made against him and abide the judgment of the court and not depart without leave thereof; or the defendant may, at his option, at the time of entering into such recognizance deposit with the county judge the amount of such recognizance in cash in lieu of surety. Upon approval of the appeal recognizance the county judge shall forthwith make a transcript of the proceedings before him and shall deliver such transcript with all the files and the recognizance in the case to the clerk of the district court, who shall thereupon enter the cause upon the criminal appearance docket of the court, together with the date of filing the transcript and recognizance, the date and amount of the recognizance, the names of the sureties, and the amount of costs taxed in the county court, whereupon the case shall be considered as of record in such court and shall be proceeded upon as provided by law in cases of appeals in criminal cases from the county courts; provided, that in an appeal involving a complaint filed for violation of a municipal ordinance, the case shall be tried by the court without a jury. 
(Ord. No. 1563-77, § 3, 1-3-77)  
Sec. 11½-19. - Bills of exceptions. 
On the trial of any case before a county judge it shall be his duty to sign any bill of exceptions tendered to him after a trial, provided the truth of the matter is fairly stated, and thereupon said exceptions shall be entered in the record of such trial. Any final conviction, sentence or judgment of the county judge may be examined into by the district court according to law, and proceedings in the court below may be stayed as may be deemed reasonable. 
(Ord. No. 1563-77, § 4, 1-3-77)  
Sec. 11½-20. - Judgments; enforcement. 
If the defendant is found guilty, the county judge shall declare the punishment which, in cases arising under the ordinances of the city or provisions of this Code, shall be by fine or imprisonment, or both, and shall render judgment according to law. It shall be a part of the judgment that the defendant stand committed until the judgment to be complied with, and all fines and costs are paid. It shall be lawful to further provide, as part of the judgment, that, until such judgment is complied with and such fine and costs are paid, the defendant be required to work out said fine and costs upon the public streets, or at any other place that may be provided, at the rate of six dollars ($6.00) per day for each day the defendant shall actually work. In any case where the defendant establishes to the satisfaction of the county judge that he is unable to make immediate payment of such fine and costs by reason of indigency, the county judge may modify the judgment by ordering such fine and costs may be paid in installments of such amounts and at such times as may be reasonable and proper, upon default in which the defendant may be committed as above provided, or the county judge may enter such other and further order as may be reasonable and proper. Any person who fails to comply with the terms of such installment order shall be liable for punishment for contempt, unless he has the leave of the court in regard to such noncompliance. 
(Ord. No. 1563-77, § 5, 1-3-77)  
Chapter 12 - DOCKS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 12-1. - State law applicable. 
Sections 13-1401 to 13-1417, inclusive, Reissue Revised Statutes of Nebraska, 2007, and amendments thereto, and now duly approved insofar as applicable shall be a part of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1027, §18, 2-21-59; Ord. No. 2765-09, § 1, 7-20-09)  
Secs. 12-2—12-16. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DOCK BOARD[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
 
Sec. 12-17. - Created. 
There is hereby created in and for the city a board of public docks which shall be known as the "Dock Board of Nebraska City, Nebraska." 
(Code 1938, Ch. 12, Art. 1, § 1; Ord. No. 1027, § 1, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-18. - Corporate body. 
The dock board shall be a body corporate and politic and shall possess all the usual powers of a corporation for public purposes, and in its name may sue or be sued, purchase, hold and sell personal property and real estate. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 1, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-19. - Composition. 
The dock board shall be composed of seven (7) members, who shall be known as commissioners of public docks. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 1, 2-21-59)  
Sec 12-20. - Qualifications. 
The commissioners of the dock board shall have been residents of the city for a period of not less than five (5) years preceding their appointment and shall be prominently identified with the commercial and business interests of the city. They shall not at the time of their appointment or during their respective terms of office be interested in or be employed by any common carrier. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 2, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-21. - Appointment. 
The commissioners of the dock board shall be appointed by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 2, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-22. - Terms. 
The commissioners of the dock board shall, serve for terms of three (3) years each; provided however, that such commissioners shall be appointed in such fashion that their terms shall be staggered. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 2, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-23. - Qualifying for office. 
The commissioners of the dock board shall qualify for office by taking oath for the faithful performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 2, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-24. - Removal of commissioner. 
If any commissioner of the dock board shall at any time during his term of office cease to have the qualifications required for his appointment or shall willfully violate any of his duties under the law, such commissioner shall be removed by the council after written charges have been preferred against him and a due hearing of such charges shall have been had by the council upon reasonable notice to such commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 3, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-25. - Vacancies. 
Vacancies occurring in the membership of the dock board through resignation or otherwise shall be filled by the council for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 3, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-26. - Compensation. 
The commissioners of the dock board shall serve as such without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 2, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-27. - Office. 
The dock board shall maintain an office and keep a record of all its proceedings and acts, and books of account shall at all times be open to the public for inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 3, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-28. - Organizational meeting. 
Within ten (10) days after their appointment, the commissioners of the dock board shall meet and organize by the election from among their number a president, vice-president and a treasurer of the board; and shall elect a secretary who need not be a member of the board. Any two such offices, except president and vice-president, may be held by one commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 2, 2-2-59)  
Sec. 12-29. - Rules and regulations authorized. 
The dock board shall from time to time adopt rules and regulations consistent with the provisions of this chapter and state law, which shall be adopted by resolution and shall be recorded in a book kept by the board and known as the book of rules and regulations. Such rules and regulations shall be in force and effect after one (1) publication in some legal newspaper published in or circulating in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1027, §§ 2, 3, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-30. - Enforcement of rules, regulations. 
Obedience to the rules and regulations of the dock board may be enforced in the name of the city by a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days; provided, the city council shall first adopt the same in ordinance form, as ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 12, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-31. - Comprehensive plan. 
The dock board shall have the power and it shall be its duty for and in behalf of the city to prepare or cause to be prepared a comprehensive general plan for the construction and improvement of its harbor, waterfront, dock, and terminal facilities as it may deem necessary, to promote commerce and for the convenient and economical accommodation and handling of watercraft of all kinds and of freight and passengers, and the free interchange, receipt, and delivery of traffic between water and land transportation agencies. Such plan shall be filed in the office of the board and be open to public inspection, and may from time to time be changed, altered or amended by the board, as the requirements of shipping and commerce and the advance of knowledge and information on the subject may suggest. The board shall procure or construct such harbor, waterfront, dock, and terminal facilities in accord with such plan. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 4, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-32. - Acquisition of property. 
The dock board shall have power to purchase or acquire by any lawful means, such personal property and lands or rights or interest therein, including easements and leaseholds, as may be necessary for use in the provision and in the construction of any publicly owned harbor and terminal facilities and appurtenances as provided for in such plan as may be adopted by the board. If the board shall deem it proper and expedient that the city shall acquire possession or ownership of such property and lands or rights or interest therein, including easement and leaseholds, and no price can be agreed upon by the board and the owner or owners thereof, the board may cause legal proceedings to be taken to acquire same for the city by the exercise of the right of eminent domain hereby conferred. The procedure to condemn property shall be exercised in the manner set forth in state law. The title of all lands, property, and rights acquired by the board shall vest in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 5, 2-21-59) 
State Law reference— Acquisition of property, R.R.S. 1943, § 76-704 et seq.  
Sec. 12-33. - Control of property. 
The city may turn over any property owned by it to the dock board to be controlled by it; and the board shall have exclusive charge and control of all such property turned over to it and all harbor and water terminal structures, facilities, and appurtenances connected therewith, and which the city or the board may acquire under the provisions hereof or otherwise. The board shall have the exclusive charge and control of the building, rebuilding, alteration, repairing, operation and leasing of said property, and every part thereof, and of the cleaning, grading, paving, sewering, dredging and deepening necessary in and about the same. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 6, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-34. - Jurisdiction. 
The dock board is hereby vested with jurisdiction and authority over that part of any street and alley and public grounds of the city which may abut upon or intersect its navigable waters, lying between the harbor line and the first intersecting street measuring backward from high watermark, to the extent only that may be necessary or requisite in carrying out the powers vested in it by this article and state law. It is hereby declared that such jurisdiction and authority shall include the right to build retaining or quay walls, docks, levees, wharves, piers, warehouses or other constructions, including belt railways and railway switches, across and upon such streets and alleys and public grounds and all other property owned or acquired by it or by the city for such purposes, and to grade, fill, and pave the same to conform to the general level of the wharf, or for suitable approaches thereto; provided, that such improvements shall be paid out of funds in the hands of the board and not be assessment against abutting property. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 7, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-35. - Control of waterfront, harbor. 
The dock board is also vested with exclusive regulation and control of the harbor and the waterfront within or abutting upon the territorial limits of the city, consistent with the laws of the United States governing navigation, and may make reasonable rules and regulations governing the traffic and use thereof, and to promote the sanitary condition of said harbor and waterfront and to prevent the pollution of the waters within said harbor and governing the use and improvement of riparian land, and structures thereon, within and abutting upon the territorial limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 8, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-36. - Participation in regulatory proceedings. 
The dock board shall have authority, either alone or jointly with any similar body, to petition any interstate commerce commission, railway commission or any like body or any federal, municipal, state or local authority, administrative, executive, judicial or legislative, having jurisdiction in the premises, for any relief, rates, charges, regulations or action which in the opinion of said body may be designed to improve or better the handling of commerce in and through the said harbor or port, or improve terminal or transportation facilities therein. It may intervene before any such body in any proceeding affecting the commerce of said harbor or port and in any such matters, the board shall be considered, along with other interested persons, one of the official representatives of the district in which said harbor or port is situated. The board shall have the authority to promote maritime and commercial interests of the harbor or port by the proper advertisement of its advantages and by the solicitation of business, through agencies established within or without said harbor or port within the United States or in foreign countries; and it shall endeavor to bring to the attention of the people of this state, and of other states which may be properly served by the harbor or port, the economical advantages to be derived from the use of the harbor or port and its facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 10, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-37. - Regulate rates, charges. 
The dock board shall have the power to fix and regulate and from time to time to alter the tolls, fees, and other charges for all facilities under its management and control and for the use thereof, which charges shall be collectible by the board and shall be reasonable and with the view of defraying the capital expenditures, interest charges, maintenance and operating expenses, and indebtedness of the board in constructing and operating the improvements and works herein authorized. The charges shall be adopted by resolution and shall be recorded in the board's book of rules and regulations. A schedule of such charges shall be enacted by the board, and a certified copy thereof shall be transmitted to the city clerk in like manner as other rules and regulations of the board, and the clerk shall forthwith cause the same to be published in the same manner as other rules and regulations of the board, and such charges shall be in force and effect from and after the date of publication. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 11, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-38. - Employ personnel. 
The dock board shall have power to employ such harbor masters, managers, assistants, attorneys, engineers, employees, clerks, workmen, and laborers as may be necessary in the efficient and economical performance of the work authorized by state law. All officers, places, and employment in the permanent service of the board shall be provided for by resolution duly passed by the board and recorded in the board's book of rules and regulations, and a certified copy thereof shall be transmitted to the city clerk as provided for other rules and regulations of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 13, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-39. - Construction work; bids. 
In the construction of docks, levees, wharves, and their appurtenances, or in contracting for the construction of any work or structures authorized by state law, the dock board shall proceed only after full and complete plans, approved by the board, and specifications for said work, have been prepared and submitted and filed with the board by its engineer for public inspection, and after public notice asking for bids for the construction of such work, based upon such plans and specifications, has been published in some legal newspaper of general circulation, published within the city, or if none is so published, then in the nearest legal newspaper, published in this state. Such publication shall be made at least thirty (30) days before the time fixed for the opening of said bids and contracting for such work. A contract may then be made with the lowest responsible bidder therefor, unless the board deems the bids excessive or unsuitable, in which event it may proceed to readvertise for bids, or the board may do the work directly, purchasing such materials and contracting for such labor as may be necessary without further notice or proposal for bids; except that it shall make no purchase of materials in amounts exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) except by public letting upon ten (10) days' notice, published as aforesaid, specifying the materials proposed to be purchased; provided, however, that said public letting shall not be required in case no satisfactory bids are received, or in case of an emergency where the delay of advertising and public letting might cause serious loss or injury to the work. The board shall, in all cases, have the right to reject any and all bids, and may either readvertise therefor, contract with others at a figure not exceeding that of the lowest bidder without further advertising, or do the work directly as hereinbefore provided. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 14, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-40. - Appropriations. 
The dock board may, at such times as it may deem necessary, file with the city council an estimate of the amounts necessary to be appropriated by the council to defray the expense of the board. The council is hereby authorized and empowered, in its discretion, to appropriate from its general fund and to place at the disposal of the board an amount sufficient to defray such expense. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 15, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-41. - Bonds. 
Whenever the dock board shall deem it necessary or advisable to issue bonds for the purpose of constructing any of the works or improvements herein authorized, or purchasing property for said purpose or maintaining or operating the same, the board shall petition the city council to issue such bonds stating the purpose for which the bonds are requested. Thereupon the council may, in its discretion, issue revenue bonds of the city, the principal and interest of which shall be payable solely out of revenue to be derived from tolls and other charges and receipts from the use and operation of the docks and other property. The city shall incur no indebtedness of any kind or nature upon the issuance of such bonds, and they shall so recite, and to support the use and operation of the docks and other property the city shall not pledge its credit nor its taxing power nor any part thereof. The proceeds of the bonds when issued shall be paid to the city treasurer and credited to the dock fund. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 16, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-42. - Fiscal procedures. 
All funds collected by the dock board, or appropriated by the city council for dock purposes from the proceeds of bonds or otherwise, shall be deposited with the city treasurer and disbursed by him only upon warrants or orders duly executed as provided by law for the execution of warrants or orders of the city and which shall state distinctly the purpose for which the same are drawn; and a permanent record shall be kept by the board of all warrants or orders so drawn, showing the date, amount, consideration, and to whom payable. When paid, the same shall be canceled and kept on file by the city treasurer. The books of the board shall from time to time be audited upon the order of the council in such manner as it may direct, and all such books and records of the board shall at all times be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 17, 2-21-59)  
Sec. 12-43. - Annual report. 
The dock board shall annually make to the city council a full and complete report of its activities, including a statement of the commerce passing through the port, and a report of the receipts and disbursements made by or on account of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1027, § 15, 2-21-59)  
Chapter 13 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Election of officers generally, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-302.01 et seq.; municipal election code, R.R.S. 1943, § 19-3001 et seq.; elections generally, R.R.S. 1943, Ch. 32. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Governed by statutes. 
Councilmen and other elective city officers shall be nominated and elected, and all elections in this city shall be held in the manner provided by the statutes of this state relating to elections in cities of the first class under the commission form of government. In matters in which such special statutes, or the ordinances of the city, lawfully enacted, make no specific provisions, the general election laws of the state so far as they are applicable to the situation, shall prevail.  
Sec. 13-2. - Exit polls. 
No person shall conduct any exit poll, public opinion poll, or any other interview with voters on election day seeking to determine voter preference within twenty (20) feet of the entrance of any polling place room or, if inside the polling place building, within one hundred (100) feet of any voting booth. 
(Ord. No. 1973-86, § 1, 5-19-86) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1973-86, § 1, adopted May 19, 1986, added § 13-40 to Ch. 13. At the discretion of the editor, and for purposes of classification, said section has been redesignated § 13-2 herein. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 32-1221.  
Secs. 13-3—13-16. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Wards, elections districts, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 16-104, 16-105. 
 
Sec. 13-17. - Division. 
The city is hereby divided into four (4) wards. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 1, Art. 2, § 1)  
Sec. 13-18. - Ward 1—Described. 
Ward number 1 of the city shall consist of all territory in the city lying east of the center line of Fifth Street, as such street shall be extended or continued. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 1, Art. 2, § 1)  
Sec. 13-19. - Ward 2—Described. 
Ward number 2 of the city shall consist of all territory in the city between the center line of Fifth Street and the center line of Ninth Street, as such streets shall be extended or continued. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 1, Art. 2, § 1)  
Sec. 13-20. - Ward 3—Described. 
Ward number 3 of the city shall consist of all territory in the city between the center line of Ninth Street and the center line of Thirteenth Street, as such streets shall be extended or continued. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 1, Art. 2, § 1)  
Sec. 13-21. - Same—Precinct A. 
Precinct A of ward 3 of the city shall consist of all territory in ward 3 lying north of the center line of Central Avenue.  
Sec. 13-22. - Same—Precinct B. 
Precinct B of ward 3 of the city shall consist of all territory in ward 3 lying south of the center line of Central Avenue.  
Sec. 13-23. - Ward 4—Described. 
Ward number 4 of the city shall consist of all territory in the city lying west of the center line of Thirteenth Street, as such street shall be extended or continued. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 1, Art. 2, § 1)  
Sec. 13-24. - Same—Precinct A. 
Precinct A of ward 4 of the city shall consist of all territory in ward 4 lying north of Central Avenue that is west of the center line of Thirteenth Street and east of the center line of Nineteenth Street. 
(Ord. No. 1781-81, § 1, 6-1-81; Ord. No. 1808-82, § 1, 2-15-82)  
Sec. 13-25. - Same—Precinct B. 
Precinct B of ward 4 of the city shall consist of all territory in ward 4 lying south of the center line of Central Avenue.  
Sec. 13-26. - Same—Precinct C. 
Precinct C of ward 4 of the city shall consist of all territory in ward 4 lying north of Central Avenue and west of the center line of Nineteenth Street. 
(Ord. No. 1781-81, § 2, 6-1-81; Ord. No. 1808-82, § 2, 2-15-82) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1781-81, § 2, adopted June 1, 1981, amended § 13-26 to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 13-26 pertained to polling places and was derived from Code 1938, Ch. 1, Art. 2, § 2.  
Sec. 13-27. - Polling places. 
Each ward or precinct shall have a polling place or polling places to be selected as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1781-81, § 3, 6-1-81)  
Chapter 14 - ELECTRICITY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building, Ch. 9; fire protection and prevention, Ch. 15; housing, Ch. 19; mobile homes, Ch. 21; planning, Ch. 28; utilities, Ch. 36. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Electric apparatus. All wires, wiring, materials, machinery, appliances, equipment, fixtures and apparatus used or designed to be used in the utilization of electricity when connected with a source of electromotive force for the purpose of producing light, heat or power. 
Electrician. The person licensed under the provisions of this chapter to install electric apparatus. 
Install, installed, installation. The construction and placing in position for service and use of any new electric apparatus, and the alteration, modification or repair of existing electric apparatus. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 4, Art. 2, § 6)  
Sec. 14-2. - Liability not affected. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to remove or lessen the liability of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing any electrical equipment for damages to any person or property injured by any defect therein, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein or the licenses or permits issued hereunder. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 4, Art. 2, § 29)  
Secs. 14-3—14-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLES II, III. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2766-09, § 1, adopted July 20, 2009, repealed former Art. II, §§ 14-18—14-26 and former Art. III, §§ 14-37—14-47, in their entirety. Former Art. II pertained to the office of the electrical inspector and derived from the Code of 1938. Former Art. III pertained to city electrician's licenses and derived from Ord. No. 2407, §§ 1—11, adopted April 27, 1997. 
 
Secs. 14-18—14-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2770-09, Arts. 1, 2, adopted July 20, 2009, repealed former Art. IV, §§ 14-59—14-69, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code of 1938. 
 
Sec. 14-60. - When not required. 
No permit required by this article shall be required for the following work: 
(a)  The installation of any electric apparatus used or useful in the connection with any generating plant or distribution system operated under a franchise granted by the city. 
(b)  For minor repair work, such as repairing flash and snap switched, replacing fuses, changing lamp sockets and receptacles, taping bare joints and repairing drop cords. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-61. - Work to be performed by licensed electricians. 
It shall be unlawful for any electrician to have any person other than a person holding a Nebraska State Electrical Board License or journeyman electrician perform any electrical work. All work will be inspected by a State of Nebraska Electrical Inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-62. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of electrical wiring or repair as an electrician or contracting electrician in this city, or to commence or take charge of any work as an electrician, without first having procured from the city a permit to work as required by this article. No such permit shall be issued by the city clerk until directed. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-63. - Application. 
The application for a permit required by this article shall be made in writing to the city clerk on forms furnished by said clerk and the applicant shall give full name under which the business is to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-64. - Licensing of firms, corporations, etc. 
In case of a partnership or firm consisting of more than one (1) person, only one (1) of such persons shall be required to qualify as a licensed electrician.  
Sec. 14-65. - Electrician bond. 
Before any electrician permit to work is issued, the applicant therefore shall file with the city clerk-treasurer a bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), executed by the applicant and a surety company authorized to do business in this state as surety, running to the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the licensee of all work in full compliance with all provisions of the city Code and any person injured by failure of such licensee to comply with the provisions of the city Code shall have a right of action against the licensee and his surety in his name; provided, however, that any person wishing to avail himself of the benefits of the surety bond shall commence action thereof within one (1) year after the date of the completion of the work alleged to have been improperly performed. The bond herein required shall be in force upon date of application and be continually in force during the year for which the permit to work is issued, in form and substance as herein required, shall be given by such person to cover all work he shall perform during such year. Any such bond shall be approved as to form and legal content by the city attorney. A permit to work as hereinabove provided may be issued upon approval of such surety bond, provided the requirements hereof are fulfilled. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-66. - Record of licenses to be kept. 
The city clerk shall make and keep a record of all permits issued, lapsed and revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-67. - Term. 
All permits issued under this article shall continue in force until January first after date on which it was granted. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-68. - Renewal. 
Permits, at the time of their expiration, may be renewed by the city clerk, upon the written recommendation of the building inspector, upon payment of the annual permit fee and registration or renewal fee, and upon condition that registrant's bond for the renewal permit period is approved and on file. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-69. - Permits not transferable. 
No initial permit or renewal permit issued pursuant to thee provisions of this article shall be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2770-09, Art. 2, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 14-70. - Registration fees. 
The following fees shall be charged for the registration of electricians to work in the city: 
(a)  Registration to work, electrician ..... $35.00 
Penalty for failure to renew within three (3) months of expiration ..... 5.00 
(b)  Registration of journeyman electrician ..... 5.00 
(Ord. No. 2819-10, § 1, 11-15-10)  
Secs. 14-71—14-79. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
 
Sec. 14-80. - National Electric Code adopted. 
The city hereby adopts the provisions of the 1996 edition of the National Electric Code 1996, ANSI/NFPA-70, as adopted by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc., the provisions of which are hereby adopted as the minimum standards for the installation of all electrical apparatus, devices and equipment within the jurisdiction of the city except as otherwise provided for in this chapter, and the same is hereby made a part of this chapter as fully and to the same extent as if copied in full and shall be considered adopted and of full force and effect within the city upon the approval thereof by the council and the filing of one (1) copy thereof in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 4, Art. 2, § 27; Ord. No. 1621-77, § 1, 12-19-77; Ord. No. 1767-81, § 1, 1-5-81; Ord. No. 1782-81, § 1, 6-15-81; Ord. No. 1884-83, § 1, 11-7-83; Ord. No. 2018-87, § 1, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2114-90, § 1, 3-5-90; Ord. No. 2260-93, § 1, 2-15-93; Ord. No. 2397-96, § 1, 11-18-96) 
State Law reference— Adoption of standard codes, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-132.  
Sec. 14-81. - Conflicts. 
In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the code adopted by this article and applicable provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation shall prevail and be controlling.  
Sec. 14-82. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2114-90, § 2, adopted March 5, 1990, repealed former § 14-82, which adopted by reference subsequent editions of the electrical code adopted by this article and derived from Ord. No. 2018-87, § 2, adopted Apr. 20, 1987.  
Sec. 14-83. - Definitions. 
Where the code adopted by this article makes reference to "the authority having jurisdiction," it shall be construed to mean the City of Nebraska City. 
Whenever the word "municipality" or the word "city" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska. 
Whenever the term "corporate counsel" or "city attorney" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the city attorney of this city. 
(Ord. No. 2018-87, § 3, 4-20-87)  
Sec. 14-84. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of the ordinance and code adopted by the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished as provided by section 1-8 of this Code. Each day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.  
Chapter 15 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building, Ch. 9; use of fire apparatus under civil defense, § 11-1; electricity, Ch. 14; housing Ch. 19; mobile homes, Ch. 21; planning, Ch. 27; unlawful to dispose of snow or ice on fire hydrant or street, §§ 33-78.5; following fire apparatus prohibited, § 35-159; crossing fire hose, § 35-160; traffic control at fires, § 35-161; utilities, Ch. 36; zoning regulations, App. A; subdivision regulations, App. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 15-1. - False fire alarms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously raise a false alarm or false report of a fire within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1256, § 2,11-6-67)  
Sec. 15-2. - Hindering fireman. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder or obstruct in any manner the chief of the fire department or any other member of the fire department in the performance of his duty. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 7, Art. 1, § 20)  
Sec. 15-3. - Assistance at fires. 
The chief of the fire department, or his assistant in charge of operations at a fire, may command the services of any person present at such fire in extinguishing the same or in the removal and protection of property; and, it shall be unlawful for any such person to refuse or fail to perform such requested service. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 7, Art. 1, § 22)  
Sec. 15-4. - Open burning ban, waiver. 
(a)  There shall be a statewide open burning ban on all bonfires, outdoor rubbish fires, and fires for the purpose of clearing land. The fire chief or his or her designee may waive an open burning ban issued under this section for an area under his or her jurisdiction by issuing an open burning permit to a person requesting permission to conduct open burning. Said permit issued by the fire chief shall be in writing, signed by the fire chief, and on a form provided by the state fire marshal. 
(b)  The fire chief or his or her designee may waive the open burning ban in his or her district when conditions are acceptable to the chief. Anyone burning in such district when the open burning ban has been waived must notify the fire department of his or her intention to burn. 
(Ord. No. 1750-80, § 1, 8-4-80; Ord.; No. 1835-82, § 1, 10-18-82)  
Sec. 15-5. - Fires regulated. 
It shall be lawful to build or set out certain fires; provided, that the person building such fires shall have the substance to be burned in a fireproof trash burner or incinerator with a metal fireproof screen of not more than one-inch mesh, and located at least twenty (20) feet from any building. The incinerator shall be built in such a way as to not permit the escape of burning paper or other substance. If any person shall require a fire in the course of his trade as a blacksmith or mechanic, such fire shall be built, and maintained in the manner prescribed by the fire chief. All fires shall be built after 7:00 a.m. and completely extinguished by 8:00 p.m., except the aforesaid fires used in the course of a trade which shall be allowed during such hours as the fire chief shall prescribe. It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to, burn, or cause to be burned any garbage, animal matter, or vegetable matter. The burning of straw, hay, leaves, or brush in the open air is hereby permitted and allowed; provided, that the person setting out the same request permission and receive an open burning permit in writing, signed by the local fire chief, on a form provided by the state fire marshal; and provided further, that any such burning shall be done while the said fire is attended by the person setting out the same at all times, and further provided that the said fire shall be located at least twenty (20) feet from any building. 
(Ord. No. 1835-82, § 3, 10-18-82)  
Sec. 15-6. - Fire pits. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Fire pit shall mean open burning for recreational or cooking purposes if performed in an approved container constructed of steel, brick, or masonry. 
Woodburning fire pit includes belowground pits, freestanding fireplaces, and portable devices intended to contain and control outdoor fires. 
Belowground fire pits shall be at least four (4) inches in depth and surrounded on the outside, aboveground, by a non-combustible material such as steel, brick, or masonry. 
(Ord. No. 2909-13, § 1, 5-6-13)  
Sec. 15-7. - Prohibited burning. 
Only natural firewood/commercial logs may be burned. Burning that is offensive or objectionable because of smoke or odor emissions, or when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous, shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2909-13, § 1, 5-6-13)  
Sec. 15-8. - Hours of operation. 
A person shall not maintain any outdoor burning from 2:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m., unless permitted and approved by the fire code official. 
(Ord. No. 2909-13, § 1, 5-6-13)  
Sec. 15-9. - Location. 
All fire pits must be located twenty (20) feet away from combustible materials such as a house, deck, accessory building or neighbor's house. 
(Ord. No. 2909-13, § 1, 5-6-13)  
Sec. 15-10. - Size. 
The maximum size of the fire pit shall be three (3) feet in diameter and the maximum height of combustible materials used in said pit shall be no more than two (2) feet in height. 
(Ord. No. 2909-13, § 1, 5-6-13; Ord. No. 2910-13, § 1, 5-20-13)  
Sec. 15-11. - Tended. 
The fire must be constantly attended and supervised until the fire has been completely extinguished. (A spark screen, while not required, is recommended.) 
(Ord. No. 2909-13, § 1, 5-6-13)  
Sec. 15-12. - Extinguishment authority. 
The fire code official is authorized to order the extinguishment by the responsible person or the fire department, of any burning that creates or adds to a hazardous or objectionable situation. 
(Ord. No. 2909-13, § 1, 5-6-13)  
Sec. 15-13. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, adopted Sept. 29, 2008, amended former Art. II, §§ 15-14—15-33, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1938 and Ord. No. 2075-89, § 1, adopted April 3, 1989. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; fire department retirement committee, § 2-214; group life insurance of volunteer firemen, § 2-237; civil service for firefighters, § 2-286 et seq.; fire insurance tax; 34-15. 
 
Sec. 15-14. - Composition. 
The fire rescue department of this city shall be composed of a fire division and EMS division, composed of such paid firefighters and emergency medical technicians as shall be employed by the mayor and council and those volunteer members of the department subject to call in the event of fire or emergency medical call. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-15. - Chief, assistants—Generally. 
The chief of the fire rescue department of the city shall have, under the direction of the mayor, control and command of the fire rescue department of the city and of the property, implements and apparatus used in said department. He shall also perform such duties as are provided by the ordinances of the city relating to the fire rescue department and fire rescue regulations. The assistant chiefs of the fire rescue department of the city shall at all times assist the chief of the fire rescue department in the performance of his duties, and shall, in the absence of the chief of the fire rescue department, succeed to the office and duties of said chief. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-16. - Same—Continuous duty. 
The chief of the fire rescue department and his assistant chiefs shall be on duty at all times, both night and day. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-17. - Powers, duties of firefighters generally. 
All members of the fire rescue department shall be subject to such rules and regulations, and shall perform such duties, as shall be prescribed or required of them by the chief of the fire rescue department or the ordinances of the city. All members of the fire division shall, during the time of fire or great public danger, have and exercise the powers and duties of policemen and shall have full power and authority to arrest all persons guilty of any violation of the city ordinances or the statute laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-18. - Rules and regulations—Generally. 
The chief of the fire rescue department shall have the power and authority to prescribe and establish from time to time such rules and regulations as he may deem advisable and necessary for the proper control and command of all persons connected with the fire rescue department of the city, its organizations, government and discipline. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-19. - Same—To members. 
Each member of the fire rescue department shall be furnished with a copy of the rules and regulations established by the chief of the fire rescue department for the government of said department. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-20. - Physical examination. 
All members of the fire and rescue department may be required to submit to a physical examination and/or random drug testing once each year, and at any other times required by the chief or by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08; Ord. No. 2764-09, § 1, 7-20-09)  
Sec. 15-21. - Custody of fire rescue apparatus. 
The chief of the fire rescue department shall have the custody, subject to the direction of the council, of the engines, vehicles, equipment, and all other property and appurtenances belonging to the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-22. - Repair of fire rescue apparatus. 
The chief of fire rescue department shall, when any of the fire engines, trucks, vehicles, equipment, and ladders, or other apparatus need to be repaired, cause the same to be repaired under his direction and supervision, by and with the advice and consent of the council. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-23. - Badges and uniforms. 
The chief of the fire rescue department shall make suitable regulations, under which the officers and personnel of the department shall be required to wear some appropriate uniform and badge, by which, in case of fires or emergencies and at other times, the authority and relation of such officers and personnel in said department may be known, as the exigencies of their duties may require. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-24. - Rules governing badges. 
Every member of the fire rescue department, when on duty, shall wear a suitable badge, furnished by the city, and any member who shall lose or destroy the same shall be required to pay the cost of replacing it; and when any member shall leave the department, shall immediately deliver the badge, and all other property belonging to the city, to the proper officer. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-25. - Suspension of members pending charges. 
During the pending of charges against any member of the department, the chief of the fire rescue department may suspend from duty any such member until such charges can be examined by him. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-26. - Records. Complaints, judgments. 
The chief of the fire rescue department shall cause to be kept, in a book for that purpose, a full and complete record of all transactions in said department, of complaints against members and the judgment of the chief thereupon, of the time lost by them, and of all property placed in his charge, and such other books and records as shall be required by the business of the department. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-27. - Preservation of property. 
The chief of the fire rescue department, or other officer in command at the scene of a fire, shall have power to cause the removal of any property, whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire, or to prevent the spreading of fire, or to protect adjoining property. The chief may direct personnel to remove any building, erection, or fence, for the purpose of checking the progress of any fire; and the chief shall have power to blow up or cause to be blown up, with powder or otherwise, any building or erection, during the progress of a fire, for the purpose of extinguishing or checking the same. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-28. - Powers to arrest. 
The chief of the fire rescue department and fire division assistant chiefs shall have power during the time of a fire and for a period of thirty-six (36) hours after its extinguishment, to arrest any suspected person, or any person hindering, resisting, conducting himself in a noisy and disorderly manner, or refusing to obey any such officer while acting in the discharge of his duty. Said officers shall be severally vested with the usual powers and authority of police officers to command all persons to assist them in the performance of such duty. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-29. - Protection of department property. 
It shall be the duty of all members of the fire division of the fire rescue department to prevent all persons not belonging to the department from entering any house, or handling any apparatus belonging to the department, without permission. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-30. - Rewards. 
The council may, for meritorious services rendered by any member of the fire rescue department in the due discharge of his duty, permit any member of said department to retain for his own benefit any reward or present tendered him therefore; and it shall be cause of removal for any such member to receive any reward or present without notice thereof to the council. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-31. - Resignation, absence without leave. 
No member of the fire rescue department, under penalty of forfeiting the salary or pay which may be due to him, shall withdraw or resign, except by permission of the chief. Unexplained absence, without leave, of any member of the fire rescue department for three (3) days, shall be cause for removal and forfeiture of all pay due; but it may, at the option of the chief be deemed and held to be a resignation by such member, and accepted as such. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-32. - Workmen's compensation coverage. 
The chief of the fire rescue department shall, on or before the first monday after the first tuesday in april in each year, furnish the city clerk for the information of the mayor and council, the roster of all members, paid or subject to call, of the fire rescue department in good standing; and from month to month thereafter shall report any proposed additions or changes in said roster for proper action of said council to the end that all members of said department shall at all times be covered by insurance or such other lawful protection to as may be provided by the mayor and counncil under the state workmen's compensation law or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08)  
Sec. 15-33. - Annual report by chief of fire rescue department. 
The annual report of the fire rescue department shall be made on or before the first day of May in each year and be transmitted to the mayor and council. It shall contain all proceedings under this article, with such statistics as the chief of the fire rescue department may wish to include therein; the chief of the fire rescue department shall also recommend therein any amendments to this article which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. A current list of the volunteer members of the fire rescue department shall be included as a part of this annual report. 
(Ord. No. 2735-08, § 2, 9-29-08) 

Chapter 17 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Health and sanitation, Ch. 18; housing, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference— Garbage disposal, R.R.S. 1943, § 19-2101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 17-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Garbage. All kitchen refuse, decayed vegetables or meats, dead animals, or anything whatsoever that will or may decompose or become offensive or dangerous to health. 
Rubbish or trash. Dirt, chips, pieces of lumber, sticks, dead trees or branches thereof, bottles, broken glass, crockery, tin cans, wooden ware, cans, boxes, straw, papers, circulars, hand bills, rags, boots, shoes, hats or any other litter or trash whatsoever. 
Waste. Cinders, ashes, plaster, brick or stone, sawdust, sand, or earth free and clear of any rubbish. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, §§ 1—3)  
Sec. 17-2. - Generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep in, on, or about any dwelling house, building or premises in the city any decayed vegetable or animal substance, garbage, offal or refuse matter or any substance that may be injurious to the public health or offensive to the residents or inhabitants of the vicinity unless the same is kept in receptacles provided therefor. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 4)  
Sec. 17-3. - Littering prohibited—Generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop, cast or deposit upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or any yard or premises, public or private, any filth of any kind, or cans, paper, trash, paper containers, rubbish, bottles, leaves, grass or any other form of litter or waste. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 4; Ch. 11, Art. 5(i), § 6; Ord. No. 2604-04, § 1, 5-17-04) 
Cross reference— Distribution of handbills, § 3-15 et seq.  
Sec. 17-4. - Same—Duty of business owners, occupants. 
(a)  Generally. The owner or occupant of any store or other place of business situated within the city shall exercise reasonable diligence at all times to keep his premises clean of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers, and other used or waste materials thrown or left on said premises by its customers, and to take reasonable measures to prevent the same from drifting or blowing to adjoining premises. 
(b)  Receptacles. Receptacles of sufficient size and number shall be placed on the premises accessible to the customers of such business where the above referred to articles of waste may be disposed of. 
(c)  Signs. Each and every business establishment shall place upon its premises in a conspicuous place or places in close proximity to the receptacle or receptacles above referred to, a sign or signs which shall, in essence, convey to its customers a request that they use such receptacles for the disposal of waste material.  
Sec. 17-5. - Same—Duty of customer. 
It shall be unlawful for any customer going upon the premises of another to in any manner dispose of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers, and other used or waste materials except in receptacles provided for such purposes.  
Sec. 17-6. - Where deposits unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited any rubbish, waste or garbage on any vacant lot, public thoroughfare, street or alley or public property or any place whatsoever except the place provided by the city council or board of health. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 14)  
Sec. 17-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 1, adopted July, 20, 2000, repealed former section 17-7 in its entirety which pertained to the establishment of a city landfill and derived from the Code of 1938, ch. 8, art. 3, § 5.  
Secs. 17-8—17-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DISPOSAL REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 17-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2449, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1998, repealed former section 17-18 in its entirety which pertained to bids and contracts for city-wide collection and derived from the Code of 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 16.  
Sec. 17-19. - Garbage containers required. 
It shall be the duty of every person owning, managing, operating, leasing, renting or occupying any premises, or any place where garbage, rubbish, trash or waste accumulates, in the city, to obtain a container from the city's franchised waste collection contractor or to provide a portable, flyproof and leakproof garbage container, with a capacity of not more than thirty (30) gallons constructed of suitable material, with an airtight and properly fitting cover. The daily accumulation of garbage, rubbish, trash and waste shall be placed in such container. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 8; Ord. No. 1093, § 1, 5-15-61; Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 2, 7-20-00)  
Secs. 17-20, 17-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 3, adopted July 20, 2000, repealed former sections 17-20, 17-21, in their entirety which respectively pertained to containers for rubbish and waste and the separation of garbage and derived the Code Of 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, §§ 12, 13.  
Sec. 17-22. - Protection of contents of containers. 
Garbage containers shall be kept closed tightly except during the collection and deposit of garbage, rubbish, trash or waste. The contents of all garbage containers shall be protected so that the wind cannot blow out and scatter the same over the streets, alleys and premises of the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 8; Ord. No. 1093, § 1, 5-15-61; Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 4, 7-20-00)  
Sec. 17-23. - Location of containers. 
The containers required by this article shall be kept in the rear of the premises or in some other unobtrusive location. Containers shall be placed at a separate designated location for collection only on the days collection is scheduled. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 8; Ord. No. 1093, § 1, 5-15-61; Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 5, 7-20-00)  
Sec. 17-24. - Maintenance of containers. 
Every container required by this article shall be maintained in as sanitary condition as possible in view of the use to which it is put; and shall be thoroughly cleansed as needed. 
(Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 6, 7-20-00  
Sec. 17-25. - Conveyances. 
No person shall carry, haul or convey any garbage, rubbish, trash or waste through the streets, alleys or public places of the city, except in such a manner that none of its contents shall be spilled or strewn over, on or along such street, alley or public place. Garbage, rubbish, trash or waste shall not be held in conveyances overnight. 
No person shall carry, haul or convey for hire any garbage, rubbish, trash or waste in any vehicle unless the same shall be completely enclosed, except during the act of filling and emptying; shall be watertight; shall be equipped with a fire extinguisher; and shall be cleaned and disinfected with sufficient frequency so as not to cause offense to the eye or nose. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 3, § 10; Ord. No. 1330, § 2, 3-15-71; Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 7, 7-20-00)  
Sec. 17-26. - Required disposal. 
It shall be the duty of every person owning, managing, operating, leasing, renting or occupying any premises, or any place where garbage, rubbish, trash or waste accumulates, in the city, to dispose of the same on at least a weekly basis. Disposal may be accomplished by contracting with the city's franchised waste collection contractor for collection and disposal, by delivery to the city's transfer station during the station's posted regular operating hours accompanied by payment of the applicable fee under the transfer station's gate rate schedule, or by any other means of disposal that complies with all applicable provisions of this Code, state law and regulation, and federal law and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 8, 7-20-00)  
Secs. 17-27—17-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTOR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2505-2000, §§ 11, 12, adopted July 20, 2000, repealed former Art. III, §§ 17-36—17-42, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. III pertained to permitting of solid waste collectors and derived from the Code of 1938; Ord. No. 1330, § 1, 3-15-71; Ord. No. 1420-73, § 1, 8-20-73; Ord. No. 1699-79, § 1, 8-23-79. 
 
Secs. 17-36—17-42. - Reserved.  
Sec. 17-43. - Exclusive franchise. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or entity without a franchise agreement to haul or collect for hire any garbage, rubbish, trash or waste for others in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2505-2000, § 11, 7-20-00; Ord. No. 2975-16, § 1, 2-1-16)  
Chapter 18 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Animals and fowl, Ch. 7; building, Ch. 9; cemeteries, Ch. 10; garbage and trash, Ch. 17; housing, Ch. 19; mobile homes, Ch. 21; planning, Ch. 27; plumbing and gas, Ch. 28 public works, Ch. 31; utilities, Ch. 36; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference— Health and sanitary regulations, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-240; regulations governing lots, drainage, weeds, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-230. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 18-1. - State regulations adopted. 
A copy of the "Rules and Regulations Concerning the reporting and Control of Communicable Diseases," adopted by the Department of Health of the State of Nebraska and last revised May 8, 1984, and a copy of the "Health Services in Nebraska Schools-Policies and Procedures," revised September 1985, are on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer, and such rules and regulations, together with any alterations or amendments thereto if and when a copy of such alterations is filed with the city clerk-treasurer, are incorporated herein by reference, the same as though copied at full length in this chapter. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 3; Ord. No. 2107-89, § 1, 12-18-89)  
Sec. 18-2. - Spitting on sidewalks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to spit upon any sidewalk or crosswalk, or upon the walk, steps, approach or stairway leading to any public building or place of public gathering in the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 14)  
Secs. 18-3—18-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF HEALTH[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Health boards, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-238. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-18. - Created. 
There is hereby created a board of health in and for the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 1)  
Sec. 18-19. - Composition. 
The board of health shall consist of five (5) members: The mayor, who shall be chairperson, a physician, who shall be medical advisor, the chief of police, who shall be secretary and quarantine officer, and two other members, who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the council. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 1; Ord. No. 2388-96, §§ 1, 2, 8-5-96)  
Sec. 18-20. - Vacancy in position of medical adviser. 
In the absence or disability of the medical adviser, the mayor may appoint some other physician to act in place of the medical adviser during such absence or disability. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 3)  
Sec. 18-21. - Compensation. 
The members of the board of health shall serve as such without compensation.  
Sec. 18-22. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the board of health shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 2)  
Sec. 18-23. - Rules, regulations. 
The board of health shall enact rules and regulations to safeguard the health of the people within the city, not included in and not in conflict with any existing provisions of this Code, state law or city ordinance, which rules and regulations, when published in book or pamphlet form and three (3) copies thereof filed with the city clerk, and any amendments thereto, when so published and filed, are hereby incorporated by reference as a part of this article, as provided by law. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 2)  
Sec. 18-24. - Records. 
The board of health shall keep a record of all transactions, orders, notices and of such other action taken by it, which records shall be filed with the city clerk and be and are hereby made public records of the city and shall be accessible to the public for inspection in the office of the city clerk at all reasonable hours. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 3)  
Sec. 18-25. - Powers, duties generally. 
The board of health shall have such powers and shall perform such duties as are prescribed by state law, this Code or city ordinances, rules and regulations.  
Secs. 18-26—18-30. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY PHYSICIAN[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Appointive officers and employees, § 2-142 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-31. - Office created. 
The office of city physician is hereby created in and for the city.  
Sec. 18-32. - Qualifications. 
The person to be appointed city physician shall be a medical physician in the city, engaged in active practice of medicine.  
Sec. 18-33. - Health officer. 
The person appointed as city physician shall also act and serve as the city health officer. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 8, Art. 1, § 1)  
Sec. 18-34. - Appointment. 
The city physician shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the city council.  
Sec. 18-35. - Powers, duties generally. 
The city physician shall have such powers and perform such duties as are provided by this Code, state law and city ordinances, rules and regulations for him and for the health officer. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, § 5)  
Secs. 18-36—18-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - NUISANCES AND OFFENSIVE CONDITIONS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2611, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 21, 2004, repealed former Art. III, Divs. 1 and 2, and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from this codification and the following: Ord. No. 908, § 1, 8-6-51; Ord. No. 1564-77, §§ 2, 4, 5 1-3-77; Ord. No. 2180-91, § 1, 10-21-91. 
State Law reference— Prevention of nuisances, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 16-230 et seq., 18-1720. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-46. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article a nuisance consists of any person doing an unlawful act, or omitting to perform a duty, or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist, which act, omission, condition or thing either: 
(a)  Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; or, 
(b)  Offends decency; or, 
(c)  Is offensive to the senses; or, 
(d)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs, or tends to obstruct, or renders dangerous for passage, any stream, public park, parkway, square, street or highway in the city; or 
(e)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property; or 
(f)  Essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property, or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others; or 
(g)  Constitutes the maintaining, using, placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain in or upon any private lot, building, structure or premises, or in or upon any street, avenue, alley, park or parkway, or at any other public or private place, of any one or more of the following conditions or things which are hereby declared to be and constitute nuisances: 
(1)  Any putrid, unsound or unwholesome meat, hides, skins, feathers, or the whole or any part of any dead animal, fish or fowl. 
(2)  Privies, vaults, cesspools, dumps, pits or like places which are not securely protected from flies or rats, or which are foul or malodorous. 
(3)  Filthy, littered or trash-covered cellars, house-yards, barn-yards, stable-yards, factory-yards, vacant areas in rear of stores, vacant lots, houses, buildings or premises. 
(4)  Animal manure in any quantity which is not securely protected from flies and the elements, or which is kept or handled in violation of any provision of this Code, state law or ordinance of the city. 
(5)  Liquid household waste, human excreta, garbage, butchers' trimmings and offal, parts of fish or any waste vegetable or animal matter in any quantity; provided nothing herein contained shall prevent the temporary retention of waste in receptacles in a manner provided by the health officer of the city, nor the dumping of nonputrifying waste in a place and manner approved by the health officer. 
(6)  Tin cans, bottles, glass, cans, ashes, small pieces of scrap iron, wire metal articles, bric-a-brac, broken stone or cement, broken crockery, broken glass, broken plaster, and all trash or abandoned material, unless the same be kept in covered bins or galvanized iron receptacles approved by the health officer. 
(7)  Trash, litter, rags, accumulations of barrels, boxes, crates, packing crates, mattresses, bedding, excelsior, packing hay, straw, or other packing material, lumber not neatly piled, scrap iron, tin or other metal not neatly piled, old automobiles or parts thereof, or any other waste material, when any of said articles or materials create a condition in which flies or rats may breed or multiply, or which may be a fire danger, or which are so unsightly as to depreciate property values in the vicinity thereof. 
(8)  Any unsightly building, billboard, or other structure, or any old, abandoned or partially destroyed building or structure or any building or structure commenced and left unfinished, which said buildings, billboards or other structures are either a fire hazard, a menace to the public health or safety, or are so unsightly as to depreciate the value of property in the vicinity thereof. 
(9)  All places used or maintained as junkyards or dumping grounds, or for the wrecking and dissembling of automobiles, trucks, tractors, or machinery of any kind, or for the storing or leaving of worn-out, wrecked or abandoned automobiles, trucks, tractors, or machinery or any kind, or of any parts thereof, or for the storing or leaving of any machinery or equipment used by contractors or builders or by other persons which said places are kept or maintained so as to essentially interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property by others, or which are so unsightly as to tend to depreciate property values in the vicinity thereof. 
(10)  Stagnant water permitted or maintained on any lot or piece of ground. 
(11)  Stockyards, pig pens, cattle pens, chicken pens or any other place, building or enclosure, in which animals or fowl of any kind are confined, or premises on which are stored tankage or any other animal or vegetable matter, when said places in which said animals are confined, or said premises on which said vegetable or animal matter is stored, are maintained and kept in such a manner that foul and noxious odors are permitted to emanate therefrom, to the annoyance of inhabitants of the city, or are maintained and kept in such a manner as to be injurious to the public health. 
(12)  Pits or excavations within the city which are not being used for the purpose of building where such pits or excavations are made and the leaving of any pits or excavations in an exposed condition for a period of twenty-four (24) hours or longer. 
(Ord. No. 2611, § 1, 6-21-04)  
Sec. 18-46.1 - Parking of vehicles on residential lots.
