Editor's note— Ord. No. 1661-79, § 1, adopted Jan. 2, 1979, repealed former § 21-21 which pertained to an occupation tax on mobile homes parked in mobile home courts. Former § 21-21 was derived from Ord. No. 1084, § 19, adopted Feb. 6, 1961. 
Ord. No. 2164-91, § 2, adopted April 1, 1991, provided for the repeal of §§ 21-22—21-27 which were concerned with mobile home courts. The aforesaid derived from Ord. No. 1084, adopted February 6, 1961.  
Sec. 21-28. - New construction or remodeling. 
(a)  No person shall construct, expand, remodel or make alterations to a manufactured home community within the jurisdiction of the City of Nebraska City without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city, except that no such permit shall be required in the making of minor repairs or in the matters of general maintenance. 
(b)  Each application for an initial license to establish a newly constructed manufactured home community and each application for a permit to construct, expand, remodel or make alterations to any part of a manufactured home community, including the sanitary, water and electrical systems, must be accompanied by plans and specifications of the manufactured home community and appurtenances thereto, and in the latter instance shall also include a description of the nature, type location and extent of the proposed work. All plans and specifications shall be submitted in triplicate and must be prepared by a registered engineer or architect if the manufactured home community has or is to have facilities for fifteen (15) or more manufactured homes. 
(c)  Each manufactured home community shall have all electrical equipment and installments designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with the applicable provisions of NFPA 70, National Electric Code. However, in no case shall a manufactured home community or mobile home park in existence and operation on or before July 10, 1976, be required to comply with any electrical system standards as a condition of issuing an annual permit. 
Any manufactured home community or mobile home park in operation on July 10, 1976, shall maintain the existing park electrical system in a safe and secure condition. Any extensions, additions or alterations thereto shall meet the standards of NFPA-70, National Electric Code, including the attachments and extensions necessary for a manufactured home installation, all or any of which shall require a permit approved by the city electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2164-91, § 1, 4-1-91; Ord. No. 2166-91, § 1, 5-20-91)  
Chapter 22 - MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic regulations, Ch. 35; displaying advertising on windows of vehicles, § 3-4. 
State Law reference— Motor vehicles generally, R.R.S. 1943, Ch. 60. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 22-1. - Unnecessary smoke, odor, etc., prohibited. 
No person shall operate any motor vehicle in such manner as to permit to escape therefrom any unnecessary smoke, gas, steam or offensive odor, or in such manner as to discharge any embers, oils or residue from the fuel used in the operation thereof. Proof of the escape from such motor vehicle of any steam, smoke, gas or offensive odors shall be prima facie evidence that the same is unnecessary. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 19)  
Sec. 22-2. - Operator must be licensed. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle upon any street or highway within the city without having in full force and effect an operator's license or learner's permit to operate it as provided by state law. It shall further be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in violation of any lawful order of any court or other legally authorized agency revoking, suspending or impounding said operator's license or learner's permit. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 20) 
State Law reference— Driver's licenses generally, R.R.S. 1943, § 60-401 et seq.  
Secs. 22-3—22-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - VEHICLE REGISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Bicycle registration, § 8-17 et seq. 
State Law reference— Vehicle registration, R.R.S. 1943, § 60-301 et seq. 
 
Sec. 22-18. - Liability for violation. 
If any vehicle is found upon any street or alley within the city in violation of any of the provisions of this article, and the identity of the driver cannot be determined, the owner or person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be held prima facie responsible for such violation.  
Sec. 22-19. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or operate any motor vehicle upon any street or public way within the city without having registered it as provided by state law. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 20)  
Sec. 22-20. - Display of certificate. 
The registration certificate for a vehicle parked or operated within the city shall at all times be carried in or upon it, subject to inspection by any police officer; which, in the case of an automobile, shall be fixed in a container in plain sight in the driver's compartment of the automobile and which, in the case of a motorcycle, shall be carried either in plain sight, affixed to the motorcycle, or in the tool bag or some convenient receptacle attached to the motorcycle. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 20)  
Sec. 22-21. - Number plates required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or operate a motor vehicle upon any street or way within the city without having attached thereto the number plates furnished by the state or county in connection with such registration. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 20)  
Sec. 22-22. - Display of number plates. 
Every motor vehicle parked or operated within the city shall at all times have displayed thereon number plates as required by state law, which plates shall be securely fastened in an upright position to the vehicle so as to prevent such plates from swinging. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 20)  
Sec. 22-23. - Trailers. 
When any trailer shall be attached to any motor vehicle in use upon the streets, such trailer shall carry a duplicate registration number and rear lights as required of any other motor vehicle. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 21)  
Sec. 22-24. - License plates kept clean. 
The license plates required on every motor vehicle by laws of the state, or by the laws of any other state while such vehicle is operated within this city shall be kept clean at all times; shall be kept clear and distinct and free from grease, dust or other blurring matter so that they shall be plainly visible at all times during daylight and under artificial light in the night time; and shall be attached in such manner as to be clearly readable at a distance of one hundred (100) feet and under no circumstances shall they be obstructed by any portion of the vehicle. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 71)  
Secs. 22-25—22-34. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT 
 
Sec. 22-35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1823-82, § 6, adopted July 19, 1982, repealed former § 22-35, which pertained the requirement of a state inspection certificate and was derived unamended from the original codification. 
State Law reference— Motor vehicle inspection, R.R.S. 1943, § 60-1701 et seq.  
Sec. 22-36. - Rear-view mirror. 
No person shall drive on a street any motor vehicle unless said vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent the driver from obtaining a view of the street to the rear by looking backward from the driver's position, unless such vehicle is equipped with a mirror so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the street for a distance of at least two hundred (200) feet to the rear of such vehicle. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 22) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-775.  
Sec. 22-37. - Obstruction of windshields. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive upon a street, any vehicle with a sign, poster or other non-transparent material upon the front windshield, side wings or side or rear windows of such motor vehicle other than a certificate or other paper required to be so displayed by law. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 22) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-776.  
Sec. 22-38. - Windshield wipers. 
Every windshield on a motor vehicle shall be equipped with a device for cleaning rain, snow or other moisture from the windshield, which device shall be so constructed as to be controlled or operated by the driver of the vehicle. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 22) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-776.  
Sec. 22-39. - Lights. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any public street within the city that does not have properly functioning lights in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, §§ 24, 25) 
State Law reference— Lamp requirements for vehicles, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-778 et seq.  
Sec. 22-40. - Brakes. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any public street within the city that does not have properly functioning brakes in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 24) 
State Law reference— Brakes, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-773.  
Sec. 22-40.01. - Prohibition of use of engine brakes. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any public street within the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska, using engine brakes to slow or stop the movement of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2509-2000, § 1, 10-2-2000)  
Sec. 22-41. - Warning devices. 
Every motor vehicle while in use on the streets or alleys of the city shall be equipped with an efficient and audible warning device; provided, no vehicle, except an ambulance or official emergency vehicle, shall be equipped with a siren. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 24) 
State Law reference— Horns, etc., R.R.S. 1943, § 39-774.  
Sec. 22-42. - Mufflers. 
No person shall drive a motor vehicle on a street within the city unless such vehicle is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise or annoying smoke. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a muffler cut-out on any motor vehicle within the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 17) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-777.  
Sec. 22-43. - Projecting loads. 
When any vehicle shall be loaded in such a manner that any portion of the load extends behind the rear end of the body of such vehicle, or projects in front of the front end of any such vehicle, a red flag shall be carried by day and a red light after sunset, securely fastened in a conspicuous position at the extreme end of such load. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 75) 
State Law reference— Projecting loads, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-769.  
Sec. 22-44. - Vehicles, spilling of contents. 
All vehicles used for carrying coal, earth, cinders, sand, gravel, rock, asphalt, tar or any similar substance, shall be so constructed as to prevent the sifting or spilling of any of the contents. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 78)  
Sec. 22-45. - Tires. 
No person shall, within this city, drive, haul, operate, transport or use any traction engine, tractor, truck or other vehicle having lugs, flanges or ribs on its tires or wheels, upon the paved portion of any street or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, unless either (a) such paved portion of such street, sidewalk, or crosswalk be first protected by laying thereon planks of sufficient strength and thickness to protect the paved portion of said street, sidewalk or crosswalk from injury or damage, or unless (b) such lugs, flanges or ribs be first removed from the tires or wheels of such vehicle. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 1 (a), § 10) 
State Law reference— Tires, R.R.S. 1943, § 39-771.  
Secs. 22-46—22-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Impoundment of vehicles, § 35-292 et seq. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 60-1901 et seq. 
 
Sec. 22-56. - Determination. 
A motor vehicle shall be deemed to be an abandoned vehicle if left unattended: 
(a)  With no number plates affixed thereto, for more than six (6) hours on any public property; 
(b)  For more than twenty-four (24) hours on any public property, except a portion thereof on which parking is legally permitted; 
(c)  For more than forty-eight (48) hours, after the parking of such vehicle shall have become illegal, if left on a portion of a public property on which parking is legally permitted; or 
(d)  For more than seven (7) days on private property if left initially without permission of the owner, or after permission of the owner shall be terminated. 
For purposes of this section, "public property" shall mean any public right-of-way, street, highway, alley, park or other state, county or municipally-owned property; and "private property" shall mean any privately-owned property which is not included within the definition of public property.  
Sec. 22-57. - Prohibited. 
No person shall cause any vehicle to be an abandoned vehicle within this city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 82)  
Sec. 22-58. - When title immediately vests in city. 
If an abandoned vehicle, at the time of abandonment, has no number plates affixed and is of a wholesale value, taking into consideration the condition of the vehicle, of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or less, title thereto shall immediately vest in the city.  
Sec. 22-59. - Inquiry as to owner. 
Except for vehicles governed by section 22-58, the city, when having custody of an abandoned vehicle, shall make an inquiry concerning the last-registered owner of such vehicle as follows: 
(a)  Abandoned vehicle with number plates affixed, to the jurisdiction which issued such number plates; or 
(b)  Abandoned vehicle with no number plates affixed, to the department of motor vehicles.  
Sec. 22-60. - Notice to owner, lienholder. 
The city shall notify the last-registered owner, if any, that his vehicle has been recovered as an abandoned vehicle and that, if unclaimed, it will be sold at public auction after five (5) days from the date such notice was mailed. If the department of motor vehicles also notifies this city that a lien or mortgage exists, such notice shall also be sent to the lienholder or mortgagee.  
Sec. 22-61. - Redemption. 
Any person claiming to be the owner of any vehicle coming under the provisions of this article shall be required to pay the cost of removal and storage of such vehicle.  
Sec. 22-62. - Vestment of title after notice. 
Title to unclaimed abandoned vehicles shall vest in this city five (5) days from the date notice of recovery thereof is mailed, or if the last-registered owner cannot be ascertained, when notice of such fact is received.  
Sec. 22-63. - Proceeds of sale; disposition. 
Any proceeds from the sale of an abandoned vehicle, less any expenses incurred by the city, shall be held by the city, without interest, for the benefit of the owner of such vehicle for a period of two (2) years. If not claimed within such two-year period, such proceeds shall be paid into the general fund of such local authority.  
Sec. 22-64. - Liability for removal. 
Neither the owner, lessee, nor occupant of the premises from which any abandoned vehicle shall be removed, nor the city, shall be liable for any loss or damage to such vehicle which occurs during its removal or while in the possession of the city or its contractual agent, or as a result of any subsequent disposition.  
Sec. 22-65. - Destroy, deface, or remove parts. 
No person other than one authorized by the city shall destroy, deface or remove any part of a vehicle which is left unattended on a highway or other public place without number plates affixed or which is abandoned. Anyone violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.  
Sec. 22-66. - Owner liable for costs. 
The last-registered owner of an abandoned vehicle shall be liable to the city for the costs of removal and storage of such vehicle.  
Secs. 22-67—22-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - MOPEDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Sections 2—7 of Ord. No. 1719-79, adopted Oct. 15, 1979, not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been included as Art. V, §§ 22-81—22-85, at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 22-81. - Definition; applicable state law. 
For the purposes of this article, "moped" shall mean a bicycle with fully operative pedals for propulsion by human power, an automatic transmission, and a motor with a cylinder capacity not exceeding fifty (50) cubic centimeters, which produces no more than two (2) brake horsepower and is capable of propelling the bicycle at a maximum design speed of no more than thirty (30) miles per hour on level ground. Mopeds, their owners and their operators, shall be subject to Chapter 60, Article 4, R.R.S. of Nebraska, 1943, and amendments thereto, but shall be exempt from the requirements of Chapter 60, Articles 1, 3, 5, and 17, R.R.S. of Nebraska, 1943, and amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1719-79, § 2, 10-15-79)  
Sec. 22-82. - Operator's license required. 
No person shall operate a moped upon the streets, alleys or public highways of the city unless such person has a valid motor vehicle operator's license or a valid school or learner's permit. 
(Ord. No. 1719-79, § 3, 10-15-79)  
Sec. 22-83. - Applicable traffic regulations; exception. 
Any person who rides a moped upon a roadway shall have all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a motor vehicle under Chapter 22 and Chapter 35 of the Code of the City of Nebraska City and Sections 39-601 to 39-6,122 R.R.S. of Nebraska, 1943, and amendments thereto, except for those provisions of such sections which by their nature can have no application. Such regulations applicable to mopeds shall apply whenever a moped shall be operated upon any path set aside by the department of roads or local authority for the use of mopeds. Notwithstanding any established maximum speed limits in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour, no person shall operate any moped at a speed in excess of thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 1719-79, § 4, 10-15-79)  
Sec. 22-84. - Operation. 
(a)  Any person who operates a moped shall ride only upon a permanent and regular seat attached thereto and shall not carry any other person nor shall any other person ride on a moped unless such moped is designed by the manufacturer to carry more than one person. 
(b)  Any person shall ride only while sitting astride the seat, facing forward. Further, no person shall operate a moped while carrying any package, bundle or other article which prevents him or her from keeping both hands on the handlebars. 
(c)  No operator shall carry any person nor shall any person ride in a position that will interfere with the operation or control of the moped or the view of the operator. No person who rides upon a moped shall attach him or herself or the moped to any other vehicle on a roadway. 
(d)  A moped shall be entitled to full use of a traffic lane of any street or highway with an authorized speed limit of forty-five (45) miles per hour or less and no vehicle shall be operated in such a manner as to deprive any moped of the full use of such lane. This section shall not apply to mopeds or motorcycles operated two (2) abreast in a single lane. No person shall operate a moped between lanes of traffic or between adjacent lines or rows of vehicles. Mopeds shall not be operated more than two (2) abreast in a single lane. Any person who operates a moped on a roadway with an authorized speed limit of more than forty-five (45) miles per hour shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, and shall not ride more than single file. 
(Ord. No. 1719-79, §§ 5, 6, 10-15-79)  
Sec. 22-85. - Equipment. 
Any moped which carries a passenger shall be equipped with footrests for such passenger. No person shall operate any moped with handlebars more than fifteen (15) inches above the mounting point of the handlebars. 
(Ord. No. 1719-79, § 7, 10-15-79)  
Secs. 22-86—22-94. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - HOBBYIST PERMITS 
 
Sec. 22-95. - Permit for the restoration or repair of motor vehicles. 
A hobbyist permit for the restoration or repair of up to two (2) non-operating, wrecked, junked, or partially dismantled vehicles on any premises used for residential purposes may be granted to the resident of such premises as follows: 
(a)  Application for a hobbyist permit shall be filed in writing with the city clerk on a form provided by the city and shall contain the name and address of the applicant and the make, model, year and vehicle identification number of each vehicle to be restored or repaired. 
(b)  The vehicle(s) to be restored or repaired shall be owned by the applicant. 
(c)  The fee for such hobbyist permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per vehicle. 
(d)  All such hobbyist permits shall expire one hundred eighty (180) calendar days following the date of issuance thereof at which time the vehicle(s) identified in the hobbyist permit, if not restored or repaired to operating condition, shall be removed from the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2605-04, § 1, 5-17-04)  
ARTICLE VII. - KEEPING OF UNREGISTERED, WRECKED OR JUNKED VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 22-96. - Keeping of unregistered, wrecked or junked vehicles unlawful: exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of or in control of any property within the city of Nebraska City as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, to allow any non-operating, wrecked, junked or partially dismantled vehicle to remain on such property longer than thirty (30) days. It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any property within Nebraska City, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, to allow any motor vehicle or trailer which has been unregistered in the State of Nebraska for more than thirty (30) days to remain on such property. This section shall not apply to a vehicle in a legally erected enclosed structure; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the lawful operation of such business enterprise; a vehicle on the premise of a farmstead as defined in Neb. Rev. Stat. SS 15-905 (1943 as amended) when necessary for the operation of the farmstead; or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner; or a vehicle on the premises of a person who has obtained a hobbyist permit for the restoration of said vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2811-10, § 1, 9-20-10)  
Sec. 22-97. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, such person shall be fined in a sum not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), except that each person so convicted shall be fined in a sum of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense and not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third offense and each offense thereafter. Each day that a violation of any of the provisions of this sections continues, shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 2811-10, § 1, 9-20-10)  
Chapter 23 - NOISE 
 
Sec. 23-1. - Prohibited generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary, or unusual noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others, within the city.  
Sec. 23-2. - Horns, warning devices. 
The sounding of any horn or other warning device on any automobile, motorcycle, or other vehicle on any street or public place of the city, except as a danger warning; the creating by means of any such warning device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time, and the use of such warning device when traffic for any reason is held up shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 3, Art. 1, § 18)  
Sec. 23-3. - Operation of power mowers; construction, demolition—Restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor-driven or operated lawn mower, or to engage in any construction or demolition work within the city between the hours of 10:00 o'clock p.m. and 6:00 o'clock a.m. the following day.  
Sec. 23-4. - Same—Emergency permit. 
In the event of an emergency, a permit may be issued exempting any person from section 23-3 for any period of time specified on the face of said permit. The permit may be issued free of charge by the police department, building inspector, or board of public works, and the issuing agency shall notify the other two (2) agencies enumerated herein of said permit.  
Sec. 23-5. - Same—Government agencies, utilities. 
Section 23-3 shall not apply to emergencies of any governmental subdivision or any public utility.  
Sec. 23-6. - Radios, phonographs, etc. 
It shall be unlawful to use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated, any radio receiving set, television set, musical instrument, phonograph, car stereo or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound, in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants, or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room, vehicle, or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto, and which unreasonably disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of the neighbors and passers-by, shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine, car stereo, or device in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet from the building, structure, or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. At no time shall the words played or used on any radio receiving set, television set, phonograph, car stereo, or sound amplifying equipment, be profane, lewd, indecent, slanderous and audible at any distance beyond the room, vehicle or chamber in which such sound is being generated. 
(Ord. No. 2632-05, § 1, 4-4-05)  
Sec. 23-7. - Yelling, shouting. 
Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.  
Sec. 23-8. - Animals, fowl. 
The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long, continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any person in the vicinity shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
Cross reference— Animals and fowl, Ch. 7.  
Secs. 23-9, 23-10. - Reserved.  
Sec. 23-11. - Pile drivers, hammers, etc. 
The operation between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any pile driver, steamshovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which attended by loud or unusual noise shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.  
Sec. 23-12. - Blowers. 
The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.  
Sec. 23-13. - Screeching of tires. 
The operation of any motor vehicle in such a way as to cause the tires thereof to screech except where the same is necessarily caused in an emergency in an attempt by the operator to avoid an accident or the causing of damage or injury shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.  
Sec. 23-14. - Quiet areas. 
The using, operating or permitting to be played, used, or operated, any radio receiving set, television set, musical instrument, phonograph, car stereo or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound that is audible any distance beyond the room, vehicle, or chamber in which the sound is being generated is prohibited within one hundred feet (100) feet of schools in session, churches during times of meetings or services, or public parks. Section 23-14 shall not apply to sound amplification and public address systems used in conjunction with events at city facilities or parks. 
(Ord. No. 2632-05, § 2, 4-4-05)  
Chapter 24 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 24-1. - Criminal investigation; false information to officer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish information he knows to be false to any law enforcement officer who operates under the authority of the state or any political subdivision or court thereof, or other official, with the intent to instigate an investigation of an alleged criminal matter, or to impede an investigation of an actual criminal matter, or to wilfully make a false report alleging the existence of an emergency in which property or human life are in jeopardy to a law enforcement officer, fire department, hospital, ambulance company, or other person engaged in providing emergency medical services. 
(Ord. No. 1256, § 1, 11-6-67) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-744.  
Sec. 24-2. - Tobacco Sale to minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or give or furnish, in any way, any tobacco in any form whatever, or cigarettes, or cigarette paper, to any minor under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(e), § 2) 
Cross reference— Occupation tax on sellers of tobacco products, § 34-71. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-1021.  
Sec. 24-3. - Tobacco—Use or possession by minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of eighteen (18) years to smoke cigarettes or cigars, or use tobacco in any form whatever, or to be in possession of any tobacco product within the city. 
(b)  Any minor so charged with the violation of this section may be free from prosecution when he or she shall have furnished evidence for the conviction of the person or persons selling or giving him the cigarettes, cigars, or tobacco product. 
(Ord. No. 2417-97, § 1, 10-6-97) 
Cross reference— Occupation tax on sellers of tobacco products, § 34-71. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-1020.  
Sec. 24-4. - Resisting officers; failure to assist. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, obstruct or resist any officer, or policeman, in making any arrest or performing any duty of his office, or to refuse or neglect to assist any such officer when called upon by him in the making of any arrest, or conveying a prisoner to jail. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5 (h), § 1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-729.  
Sec. 24-5. - Impersonating officer. 
If any person other than a regular policeman, police officer, inspector, officer or employee of this city shall, within the city wear a badge similar to or resembling the badges prescribed for or furnished the police force of this city, or any inspector, officer or employee thereof, or shall falsely and wilfully impersonate or endeavor to impersonate any such policeman, officer or employee or shall falsely pretend to be a policeman, officer or employee, and shall seek to exercise any authority as such, or shall do or attempt to do any other act under color of such pretended authority, every such person shall be deemed guilty of misdemeanor. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5 (h), § 2)  
Sec. 24-6. - Radio interference. 
Any person, operating or causing to be operated any oil burner, motor, sign or other electrical apparatus within the city, or connected with the light and power system operating in said city, which shall cause unnecessary electrical interference with radio or television reception shall equip such apparatus with proper filtering attachments to eliminate said interference. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the use of necessary medical or health equipment or apparatus where said interference cannot be reasonably eliminated. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(j), § 5)  
Sec. 24-7. - Accessories after the fact. 
Whoever aids, abets or procures another to violate any provision of this Code or ordinance of the city, or whoever is an accessory after the fact to the commission of such violation, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. An accessory after the fact is a person who, after full knowledge that a violation of this Code or an ordinance has been committed, conceals it from a police officer, or harbors or protects the person charged with or found guilty of a violation of any provisions of this Code or ordinance of the city or state law. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-202.  
Sec. 24-8. - Smoking regulations in municipal buildings or motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in any municipally owned and operated buildings or motor vehicles within the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska. 
(b)  Smoking shall mean carrying a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or any other lighted smoking equipment. 
(c)  That "No Smoking" signs shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in all municipally owned and operated buildings within the City of Nebraska City. These signs shall be posted in English and such other language as the director of public properties shall determine. 
(d)  Any person who violates this section or is found guilty of defacing or removing "No Smoking" signs, as provided by this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2436-98, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 2631-05, § 1, 4-4-05)  
Secs. 24-9—24-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 
 
Sec. 24-18. - Assaults. 
(a)  Any person commits the offense of assault if he: 
(1)  Intentionally, knowingly or recklessly causes bodily injury to another person; or 
(2)  Threatens another in a menacing manner. 
(b)  Bodily injury shall mean physical pain, illness or any impairment of a physical condition. Recklessly shall mean acting with respect to a material element of an offense when any person disregards a substantial and unjustifiable risk that the material element exists or will result from his conduct. The risk must be of such a nature and degree that, considering the nature and purpose of the act or his conduct and circumstances known to him, its disregard involves a gross deviation from the standard of conduct that a law abiding person would observe in the actor's situation. 
(c)  Assault is a misdemeanor. The penalty authorized upon conviction of assault shall not exceed a maximum of six (6) months imprisonment, or a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or both. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 5; Ord. No. 2142-90, § 1, 9-17-90; Ord. No. 2168-91, § 1, 6-3-91)  
Sec. 24-19. - Provoking assault. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city intentionally to provoke or attempt to provoke an assault upon himself or another by the uttering of grossly vile or insulting epithets applied to the assailed party or one so attempting to commit an assault, or to curse or swear at a person or use grossly vile names or slander or abuse the character of another person with the intention of provoking an assault by said person. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-412.  
Sec. 24-20. - Obstructing passage, business. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the public right-of-way along street or sidewalk, or entrance to place of business, or so as to obstruct or injure the carrying on of any lawful business. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 4)  
Sec. 24-21. - Disturbing the peace. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to intentionally disturb the peace and quiet of any person, family or neighborhood. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 1; Ord. No. 2408-97, § 1, 6-2-97)  
Sec. 24-22. - Disturbing assemblies generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within this city, to disturb the peace and quiet of any public assembly for any purpose, by any loud or unusual noise, boisterous laughing or talking, halloing, quarrelling, swearing, obscene and indecent language, or by any other manner or device whatsoever. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 2)  
Sec. 24-23. - Disturbing religious meetings. 
Whoever at any time interrupts or molests any religious society or any member thereof, or any persons when meeting or met together for the purpose of worship, or performing any duties enjoined on or appertaining to them, as members of such society, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor; provided, this section shall not be so construed as to deprive any religious society of the right of laying hands upon the person or persons who may be disturbing the congregation, and turning him or them out of the church or place of worship. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art.5(f), § 2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-801.  
Sec. 24-24. - Unlawful assembly generally. 
(a)  A person is guilty of unlawful assembly if he assembles with two (2) or more persons for the purpose of engaging in conduct constituting the crime of riot or if, being present at an assembly that either has or develops such a purpose, he remains there with an intent to advance that purpose. 
(b)  Any person convicted of unlawful assembly shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-822.  
Sec. 24-25. - Unlawful riotous assembly. 
If three (3) or more persons shall assemble together with intent to do any unlawful act, with force and violence, against the person or property of another, or to do any unlawful act against the peace; or, being lawfully assembled, shall agree with each other to do any unlawful act as aforesaid, and shall make any movement or preparation therefor, the persons so offending shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-804.  
Sec. 24-26. - Disorderly conduct. 
(1)  A person is guilty of disorderly conduct if, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, he: 
(a)  Engages in fighting or threatening, or in violent or tumultuous behavior; or 
(b)  Makes unreasonable noise or offensively coarse utterance, gesture or display, or addresses abusive language to any person present; or 
(c)  Creates a hazardous or physically offensive condition by any act which serves no legitimate purpose of the actor. 
(2)  Any person convicted of disorderly conduct shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5 (f), § 3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-823.  
Sec. 24-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2207-92, § 1, adopted April 6, 1992, amended the Code by deleting provisions contained in § 24-27. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, said provisions pertained to vagrants and derived from the Code of 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 8. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-1119.  
Secs. 24-28—24-37. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ASSEMBLIES, PARADES AND PROCESSIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic regulations for parades and processions, § 35-178 et seq. 
 
Sec. 24-38. - Enforcement. 
Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the authority of any officer to arrest a person engaged in any act or activity granted a permit under this article, if the conduct of such person violates the laws of the state, provisions of this Code or ordinances of this city, or unreasonably obstructs the public streets and sidewalks of this city, or engages in acts that cause, or would tend to cause, a breach of the peace.  
Sec. 24-39. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to organize or hold or participate in any parade, meeting, assembly or procession of persons and/or vehicles on the streets or sidewalks of this city unless such activity shall have first been authorized by a written permit therefor.  
Sec. 24-40. - Application for permit. 
Any person desiring a permit required by the provisions of this article shall make application therefor to the chief of police, which application shall contain the following information: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(b)  The name and address of the person the applicant represents. 
(c)  The approximate time and date of commencement and termination of each act or activity desired. 
(d)  The purpose, location and route of such act or activity, if applicable. 
(e)  The person, group, association or body to be authorized under the permit to do such act or activity and the approximate number of persons to participate. 
(f)  Such other relevant information as the chief of police may require for the investigation of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1963-86, § 1, 3-18-86)  
Sec. 24-41. - Contents of permit. 
Upon issuance of a permit required by this article, the same shall contain therein all information contained in the application therefor and be signed by the chief of police and a signed copy of the same shall be kept with the application, both on file in the office of the chief of police.  
Sec. 24-42. - Matters considered in determining issuance of permit. 
In deciding whether to issue a permit under the provisions of this article, the chief of police shall consider: 
(a)  Number of persons to participate; 
(b)  Anticipated traffic conditions at the time and date proposed for the activity; 
(c)  Schedule of other similar activities for which permits may have been issued; 
(d)  Adequacy of adult supervision for any minors scheduled to participate; 
(e)  Availability of city personnel whose presence on duty may be required by the activity and by the necessity to protect the general public; 
(f)  Adequacy of public facilities in the location proposed for the activity to accommodate the proposed activity and the normal public use of public facilities in the proposed location.  
Sec. 24-43. - Issuance. 
The permit required by the provisions of this article shall be issued by the chief of police upon application therefor; provided however, that such permit may be denied or refused if it shall appear that the applicant therefore or the act or activity requested by such application shall be violative of any applicable provisions of this Code, state law or city ordinance.  
Sec. 24-44. - Time lapse between application, activity. 
It shall be unlawful for any activity authorized under this article to commence within five (5) days from the date of the application therefor.  
Sec. 24-45. - Deviation from permit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person participating in any act or activity for which a permit has been granted under the provisions of this article to deviate from or alter any of the terms or contents of such permit.  
Sec. 24-46. - Display of permit. 
Every person having a permit issued under the provisions of this article shall have such permit in his possession during the activity permitted thereby and shall display such permit upon the request of any law enforcement officer. Failure to display such permit shall be deemed a misdemeanor.  
Sec. 24-47. - Revocation of permit. 
Any permit issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the chief of police for the violation by the permittee of any applicable provisions of this Code, state law or city ordinance.  
Sec. 24-48. - Dispersal of activity. 
Whenever the free passage of any street or sidewalk in the city shall be obstructed by a crowd, congregation, parade, meeting, assembly or procession, or the conduct of two (2) or more persons, except as authorized by any permit issued pursuant to this article, the persons comprising said group shall disperse or move when directed to do so by a police officer. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse and said refusal shall be a violation of this article.  
Secs. 24-49—24-58. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 24-59. - Criminal mischief. 
(a)  A person commits criminal mischief if he: 
(1)  Damages property of another intentionally or recklessly; 
(2)  Intentionally tampers with property of another so as to endanger persons or property; 
(3)  Intentionally or maliciously causes another to suffer pecuniary loss by deception or threat. 
(b)  Damages shall mean the actor intentionally or recklessly causes pecuniary loss in the amount of less than three hundred dollars ($300.00), or his or her actions result in no pecuniary loss. 
(c)  Criminal mischief is a misdemeanor. The penalty authorized upon conviction of criminal mischief shall not exceed a maximum of three (3) months imprisonment or a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 1; Ord. No. 2143-90, § 1, 9-17-90; Ord. No. 2542-02, § 1, 2-18-02)  
Sec. 24-60. - Damaging public utility property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, cut, injure, remove, break, destroy or deface any pole, wire, fixture, instrument or other property of any telegraph, telephone, electric, or gas company or association used in the operation of any telegraph, telephone, electric line or gas business within the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 2)  
Sec. 24-61. - Injuring trees. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully, maliciously or wantonly cut down, destroy by girdling, or tapping or otherwise injure any tree not his own that is standing or growing for shade, ornament or any other useful purpose within the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 3)  
Sec. 24-62. - Trespassing. 
Whoever shall, other than in an emergency, purposely or knowingly enter or be upon the property of another person without being invited, licensed, or privileged to do so, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.  
Sec. 24-63. - Petit larceny. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to steal any money or goods and chattels of any kind whatsoever, of less value than one hundred dollars ($100.00), the property of another, or to steal or maliciously destroy any money, promissory note, bill of exchange, order, draft, receipt, warrant, check, or bond given for the payment of money, or receipt acknowledging the receipt of money or other property of less value than one hundred dollars ($100.00), and every person so offering shall make restitution to the party injured in two-fold the value of the property stolen or destroyed, and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 11) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-512.  
Sec. 24-64. - Shoplifting. 
A person commits the crime of theft by shoplifting when he or she, with the intent of appropriating merchandise to his or her own use without paying for the same or to deprive the owner of possession of such property or its retail value, in whole or in part, does any of the following: 
(a)  Conceals or takes possession of the goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment; 
(b)  Alters the price tag or other price marking on goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment; 
(c)  Transfers the goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment from one container to another; 
(d)  Interchanges the label or price tag from one item of merchandise with a label or price tag from another item of merchandise; or 
(e)  Causes the cash register or other sales recording device to reflect less than the retail price of the merchandise. 
In any prosecution for theft by shoplifting, in order to allow the owner or owners of shoplifted property the use of such property pending criminal prosecutions, photographs of the shoplifted property may be accepted as prima facie evidence as to the identity of the property. Such photograph shall be accompanied by a written statement containing the following: 
(a)  A description of the property; 
(b)  The name of the owner or owners of the property; 
(c)  The time, date, and location where the shoplifting occurred; 
(d)  The time and date the photograph was taken; 
(e)  The name of the photographer; and 
(f)  Verification by the arresting officer. 
Prior to allowing the use of the shoplifted property as provided in this section, legal counsel for the alleged shoplifter shall have a reasonable opportunity to inspect and appraise the property and may file a motion for retention of the property, which motion shall be granted if there is any reasonable basis for believing that the photographs and accompanying affidavit may be misleading. 
(Ord. No. 1836-82, § 2, 10-18-82)  
Sec. 24-65. - Theft by unlawful taking or disposition. 
(a)  A person shall be guilty of theft if he or she takes, or exercises control over movable property of another, with the intent to deprive him or her thereof. 
(b)  Theft constitutes a misdemeanor when the value of the thing involved is five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less. 
(c)  The penalty upon conviction of theft shall not exceed a maximum of three (3) months imprisonment or a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both. 
(Ord. No. 2543-02, § 1, 2-18-02)  
Secs. 24-66—24-73. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1940-85, § 1, adopted June 3, 1985, added a new chapter to the Code, but did specify manner of inclusion. At the discretion of the editor, and for purposes of classification, said ordinance has been included as §§ 24-77—24-83 in existing Art. V of Ch. 24. See also the editor's note following § 24-74. 
 
Sec. 24-74. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1940-85, §§ 2—8, adopted June 3, 1985, have been treated by the editors as superseding § 24-74, which section pertained to indecent exposure and was derived from Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(c), § 1. See §§ 24-77—24-83 herein.  
Sec. 24-75. - Bawdy houses. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, establish, conduct, keep, maintain, own, use or lease any building, room, tent or other structure within the limits of the city for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution. It shall also be unlawful for any person to frequent or reside in such premises. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 1, §§ 1—3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-910 et seq.  
Sec. 24-76. - Prostitution. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit any other person for sexual intercourse for hire within the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 1, § 4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-907.  
Sec. 24-77. - Definitions relative to unlawful exposure. 
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning set forth in this section: 
Exposed means the state of being revealed, exhibited or otherwise rendered open to public view. 
Expressive dance means any dance which, when considered in the context of the entire performance, constitutes an expression of theme, story, or ideas, but excluding any dance such as, but not limited to, common barroom-type topless dancing which, when considered in the context of the entire performance, is presented primarily as a means of displaying nudity as a sales device or for other commercial exploitation without substantial expression of theme, story or idea. 
Public exposure means the act of revealing, exhibiting or otherwise rendering open to public view. 
Public place means any place in which the general public has a right to be present, whether or not conditioned upon payment of a fee, and includes, but is not limited to, buildings open to the general public, whether or not access is restricted according to age, including those in which food or drink is served, or entertainment provided. 
Unlawful exposure means: 
(a)  A public exposure of any portion of the human anus or genitals; 
(b)  A public exposure of any portion of the female breast lower than the upper edge of the areola; or 
(c)  A public exposure consisting of touching, caressing or fondling of the male or female genitals or female breasts, whether clothed or unclothed; 
(d)  Any other lewd act, whether publicly performed or not. 
(Ord. No. 1940-85, § 2, 6-3-85)  
Sec. 24-78. - Unlawful exposure prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally commit any act constituting unlawful exposure as defined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1940-85, § 3, 6-3-85)  
Sec. 24-79. - Facilitating unlawful exposure prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, lessee, manager, operator, or other person in charge of any public place to knowingly permit, encourage, or cause to be committed, whether by commission or omission, any unlawful exposure upon said premises. 
(Ord. No. 1940-85, § 4, 6-3-85)  
Sec. 24-80. - Exemptions. 
The prohibitions set forth in sections 24-78 and 24-79, shall not apply to any: 
(a)  "Expressive dance" as defined in section 24-77; 
(b)  Play, opera, musical, or other dramatic work; 
(c)  Class, seminar, or lecture, conducted for a scientific or educational purpose; 
(d)  Nudity within a locker room or other similar facility when used for changing clothing in connection with athletic or exercise activities. 
(Ord. No. 1940-85, § 5, 6-3-85)  
Sec. 24-81. - Location of performers providing certain forms of entertainment restricted. 
No entertainer performing "expressive dance" as defined in section 24-77 shall appear in any public place while unclothed or with any portion of the buttocks, genitals, pubic region or female breasts exposed, except upon a stage or other surface raised at least eighteen (18) inches above the level of the floor upon which the closest patrons are seated or standing, nor closer than six (6) feet from the nearest patron. 
(Ord. No. 1940-85, § 6, 6-3-85)  
Sec. 24-82. - Affirmative defenses. 
It is an affirmative defense to a prosecution for violation of section 24-78 or 24-79 of this article that the nudity or other exposure, when considered in the context in which presented, provided actual literary, artistic, political or scientific value and was not provided for commercial or sexual exploitation or with the emphasis on an appeal to a prurient interest. 
(Ord. No. 1940-85, §7,6-3-85)  
Sec. 24-83. - Penalty. 
Violation of any of the provisions of sections 24-77 through 24-82 constitutes a misdemeanor, punishable as set forth in section 1-8 of the Nebraska City Code. 
(Ord. No. 1940-85, § 8, 6-3-85)  
Sec. 24-84. - Urinating or defecating in public; prohibited, penalty. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate on a public street, alley, or any other property, public or private, open to or visible to the public. This section shall not apply to urinating or defecating in any restroom facility in a manner for which that facility was designed. Violation of this section constitutes a misdemeanor, punishable as set forth in section 1-8 or with a waiver fine in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 3009-18, § 1, 7-16-18)  
Secs. 24-85—24-86. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 
 
Sec. 24-87. - Discharge of firearms in city limits. 
No person, except an officer of the law in the discharge of his duty, shall fire or discharge any rifle, gun, pistol, fowling piece or other firearm within this city; provided, this section shall not apply to licensed shooting galleries; nor shall it apply when necessary for the public or individual defense and safety; nor shall it apply when necessary for the carrying on of any business or the presentation of any play, theatrical or stage performance or public spectacle or exhibition duly authorized or licensed. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art 5(d), § 1)  
Sec. 24-88. - Air guns, dangerous missiles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, or cause to be discharged, any toy pistol, toy gun, air gun, bow and arrow, blank cartridge, revolver or any other arm or arms, or slingshot loaded with rock or leaden or other dangerous missiles, at any time or under any circumstances, within this city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(d), § 2)  
Sec. 24-89. - Concealed weapons. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within this city, except a permit holder possessing a valid permit under the Nebraska Concealed Handgun Permit Act, and except officers of the law in the discharge of their duties, to carry about his/her person any concealed pistol, revolver, dirk, bowie knife, billy, slingshot, metal knuckles, or other dangerous, or deadly weapon of any kind. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(d), § 3; Ord. No. 2761-09, § 1, 6-1-09)  
Sec. 24-90. - Abandoned air-tight containers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or store any icebox, refrigerator or other air-tight container within the city where the same is accessible to children unless and until the door or doors of said icebox, refrigerator or other air-tight container shall have been removed. 
This section shall not apply to iceboxes, refrigerators or other air-tight containers placed for storage in the storage warehouses or in the storage area of retail establishments in the business of selling refrigerators where such storage area is enclosed in a building or warehouse, locked and inaccessible to the public.  
Sec. 24-91. - Fireworks: Sale; permissible; license; time of sale; rules and regulations; public exhibitions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership or corporation to have possession of, for sale or for any other purpose, to offer for sale, or to use, within the corporate limits of the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska, any fireworks of any kind, except as defined as consumer fireworks by R.R.S. § 28-1241(6), and except as defined as a display fireworks by R.R.S. § 28-1241(7), as those sections may be amended from time to time. 
(b)  Fourth of July Fireworks. Consumer fireworks shall be used, or sold at retail, only between June 24 and July 5 of each year, except that a public exhibition or display of display fireworks under the provisions of § 28-1239.01 as well as subsection (f) of this section may occur the immediate weekend following July 4 if July 4 is a weekday. During such dates, it shall also be unlawful to use any consumer fireworks within the corporate limits of the city between the hours of midnight and 6:00 a.m. of any day. It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership or corporation to sell, hold for sale or offer for sale any consumer fireworks in the city, unless such person shall first make application to the city clerk for a license to sell consumer fireworks at retail. Each application shall be accompanied by a license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a local (within the city's corporate limits) non-profit organization and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a retail vendor or organization. Seventy-five (75) percent of all fees collected shall be allocated annually to the Nebraska City Fourth of July fireworks show. 
(c)  New Year's Fireworks. Consumer fireworks shall be used, or sold at retail, only between December 28 and January 1 of each year. During such dates, it shall also be unlawful to use any consumer fireworks within the corporate limits of the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any day, except it shall be lawful during the hours between 11:00 p.m. on December 31 and 1:00 a.m. on January 1. It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership or corporation to sell, hold for sale or offer for sale any consumer fireworks in the city, unless such person shall first make application to the city clerk for a license to sell consumer fireworks at retail. Each application shall be accompanied by a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a local (within the city's corporate limits) non-profit organization and fifty dollars ($50.00) for a retail vendor or organization. Seventy-five (75) percent of all fees collected shall be allocated annually to the Nebraska City Fourth of July fireworks show. 
(d)  The license shall be good for only the Fourth of July period or New Year's period beginning in the calendar year in which it is issued. 
(e)  Each application for a consumer fireworks license must be approved by the chief of the fire department, and each fireworks sale location must meet the following requirements: 
(1)  No consumer fireworks stand, tent, or structure shall be placed or located on a public right-of-way. 
(2)  All unsold stock and accompanying litter, shall be removed from the location by 5:00 o'clock p.m. on the 5th day of July and on the 2nd day of January, and shall be returned to the wholesaler or disposed of in an appropriate manner, unless the same is kept in a permanent structure approved by the chief of the fire department as a "Fireworks Building" in conformance with the Rules for Retail Sales of Consumer Fireworks adopted by the Nebraska State Fire Marshal's Office. 
(3)  All State and Federal requirements for fire extinguishers, signage and other matters, including any State adopted edition of the NFPA 1124, Code for the Manufacture, Transportation, Storage, and Retail Sales of Fireworks and Pyrotechnic Articles. 
(f)  Any public exhibition or display of fireworks under the provisions of R.R.S. § 28-1239.01 (as the same may be amended from time to time), must have submitted on forms supplied by the city clerk, a written application by the sponsoring organization to the mayor and council for their approval at least four (4) weeks prior to the date of the proposed public exhibition or display; and further, the application shall first be approved by the chief of the fire department in writing before being granted, and if granted, said permit shall provide, among other things, that said display shall be under the direct supervision and control of said chief with regard to all details affecting fire and safety hazards. No permit will be granted until evidence has been submitted to the city clerk showing that the state fire marshal has issued a state permit to conduct a public exhibition or display of fireworks. Said application shall be accompanied by an assurance that if the license is issued, the applicant shall, at the time of receipt of said license, deliver to the city clerk's office, a certificate of liability insurance with minimum coverages of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00)/three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) public liability and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage designating said city, as the owner of record, and any lessee or tenant as additional assured thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2019-87, § 1, 4-20-87; Ord. No. 2555-02, § 1, 6-3-02; Ord. No. 2768-09, § 1, 7-20-09; Ord. No. 2900-13, § 1, 3-4-13; Ord. No. 3034-19, § 1, 5-20-19)  
Secs. 24-92—24-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - GAMBLING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 24-101. - Gambling generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to engage in gambling, lottery or play any game or games of chance of any character with cards, dice or with any other device or means whatever, for money or any other valuable thing, or for anything representing money or other valuable thing except as may be provided in this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the keeper of any public place within the city to permit any gambling or playing at any game of chance in or about the premises except as may be provided in this article. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 3, §§ 2, 3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-941.  
Sec. 24-102. - Gambling house, device generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within this city, to set up, establish, maintain or keep, or to allow or permit the setting up, establishment, maintenance or keeping of, any gambling house, table, room or place whatever, or gambling device of whatever form or character, at which any game, or scheme of chance, or lottery shall be played for money or property or other valuable thing or article representing money, property or other valuable thing. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 3, § 1)  
Sec. 24-103. - Frequenting gambling house. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within this city to visit, frequent or loiter about any room or place wherein any lottery, gambling or playing at games of chance for money or articles representing money or property is conducted or permitted, knowing the same to be such a place. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 3, § 4)  
Secs. 24-104—24-108. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BINGO[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Occupation tax, § 34-31 et seq. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 9-101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 24-109. - Definition. 
A "licensed organization" as used in this division shall mean an organization licensed under the provisions of the Nebraska Bingo and Pickle Card Regulatory Act to conduct bingo. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 8-3-59; Ord. No. 1882-83, § 1, 11-7-83)  
Sec. 24-110. - Permit required. 
An organization licensed by the state to conduct the game of bingo shall obtain a written permit therefor from the mayor and city council before commencing operation of the same within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 2, 8-3-59; Ord. No. 1882-83, § 2, 11-7-83)  
Sec. 24-111. - Application. 
Any application for a permit to conduct a game of bingo as required by this division shall be in writing and filed with the city clerk-treasurer and shall follow the requirements of Section 9-142, R.R.S. of Nebraska, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 2, 8-3-59; Ord. No. 1882-83, § 3, 11-7-83)  
Sec. 24-112. - Fee. 
The fee for a permit required by this division or each renewal thereof, shall be in the sum of ten dollars ($10.00), which the applicant shall pay to the city treasurer prior to filing an application for such permit or renewal. A receipt for payment of the fee shall be filed with the application. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 8-3-59)  
Sec. 24-113. - Fee to be deposited in general fund. 
The city treasurer shall credit the fee collected under the provisions of this division to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 8-3-59)  
Sec. 24-114. - Issuance. 
The city clerk shall issue the permit to conduct a game of bingo as required by this division when directed by the city council so to do. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 8-3-59)  
Sec. 24-115. - Expiration. 
The permit to conduct a game of bingo as required by this section shall expire on September 30 following its issuance or renewal. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 8-3-59; Ord. No. 1882-83, § 4, 11-7-83; Ord. No. 2177-91, § 1, 8-19-91)  
Sec. 24-116. - Display of permit. 
A permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall, at all times, be displayed conspicuously at the place where the game of bingo is being conducted. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 8-3-59)  
Sec. 24-117. - Revocation. 
Any permit to conduct games of bingo issued under the provisions of this division may be revoked or suspended by the mayor and city council for cause or when the state license of the association has been revoked or suspended; but such revocation or suspension order shall be identical in substance with that issued by the state. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 5, 8-3-59)  
Sec. 24-118. - Games to conform to applicable laws. 
Games of bingo shall be conducted within the city strictly in accordance with all ordinances of the city, not inconsistent with state law. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 4, 8-3-59)  
Sec. 24-119. - State laws adopted; separate offenses. 
All the provisions of state statutes, as the same now exist or may hereafter be amended, shall be and do constitute a part of this division the same as if repeated verbatim herein, and violation of the same shall be distinct and separate offense against the city, as well as against the state, and any violators thereof shall be separately prosecuted by the city for each of such offenses and if convicted shall be punished as provided for the violation of other provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 8, 8-3-59)  
Sec. 24-120. - Tax levied. 
A tax of two (2) percent of the gross receipts of each organization collected as a result of conducting a game of bingo within the city, is hereby imposed and levied against each such organization, payable to the city clerk-treasurer quarterly, not later than thirty (30) days from the close of the preceding quarter, together with such reports as may be required by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 6, 8-3-59; Ord. No. 1882-83, § 5, 11-7-83; Ord. No. 2169-91, § 1, 6-17-91)  
Sec. 24-121. - Report. 
Each organization conducting a game of bingo within the city shall submit a written quarterly report to the city clerk-treasurer covering the preceding calendar quarter, not later than thirty (30) days from the close of the preceding quarter. The report shall include a detailed financial statement of each separate session of bingo conducted by such organization, prepared on forms prescribed by the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 7, 8-3-59; Ord. No. 1882-83, § 6, 11-7-83)  
Secs. 24-122—24-131. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - STATE OF EMERGENCY CURFEW[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Civil defense, Ch. 11. 
State Law reference— State of emergency, R.R.S. 1943, § 28-827 et seq. 
 
Sec. 24-132. - Proclamation. 
Whenever in the judgment of the mayor, or in the event of his inability to act the president of the council, determines that an emergency exists within the city as a result of mob action or other civil disobedience causing danger of injury to or damages to persons or property, he shall have power to impose by proclamation any regulations necessary to preserve the peace and order of the city.  
Sec. 24-133. - Restriction of activities. 
In the event a state of emergency is proclaimed under the provisions of this division, the mayor or, in his disability the president of the council, shall have the authority and power to: 
(a)  Impose a curfew upon all or any portion of the city thereby requiring all persons in such designated curfew areas to forthwith remove themselves from the public streets, alleys, parks or other public places; provided, however, that physicians, nurses, and ambulance operators performing medical services, utility personnel maintaining essential public services, firemen and city authorized or requested law enforcement officers and personnel may be exempted from such curfew. 
(b)  Order the closing of any business establishments anywhere within the city for the period of the emergency, such businesses to include, but not be limited to, those selling intoxicating liquors, cereal malt beverages, gasoline or firearms. 
(c)  Designate any public street, thoroughfare or vehicle parking areas closed to motor vehicles and pedestrian traffic. 
(d)  Call upon regular and auxiliary law enforcement agencies and organizations within or without the city to assist in preserving and keeping the peace within the city.  
Sec. 24-134. - When proclamation effective. 
The proclamation of emergency provided for by this division shall become effective upon its issuance and dissemination to the public by appropriate news media.  
Sec. 24-135. - Termination; extension. 
Any emergency proclaimed in accordance with the provisions of this division shall terminate after forty-eight (48) hours from the issuance thereof, or upon the issuance of a proclamation determining an emergency no longer exists, whichever occurs first; provided, however, that such emergency may be extended for such additional periods of time as determined necessary by resolution of the governing body.  
Sec. 24-136. - Violation of imposed restrictions. 
Any person who shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with the orders of duly authorized law enforcement officers or personnel charged with the responsibility of enforcing the proclamation of emergency authorized herein shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.  
Secs. 24-137—24-146. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - CURFEW FOR MINORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1649-78, adopted Nov. 6, 1978, amended the Code but did not specify the manner of codification, hence inclusion of §§ 2—7 thereof as Art. IX, §§ 24-147—24-152, was at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 24-147. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(a)  City is the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska. 
(b)  Minor is any person under the age of sixteen (16). 
(c)  Parent is the natural or adoptive parent of a minor. 
(d)  Guardian is any person other than a parent, who has legal guardianship of a minor. 
(e)  Custodian is any person over the age of nineteen (19) who is in loco parentis to a juvenile. 
(f)  Public place shall mean any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, park, playground or place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment or other lawful purpose. A public place shall include but not be limited to any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling alley, cafe, theater, drugstore, poolroom, shopping center and any other place devoted to amusement or entertainment of the general public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of the above. 
(Ord. No. 1649-78, § 2, 11-6-78)  
Sec. 24-148. - Curfew established. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of sixteen (16) years to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, play or be in or upon the public streets, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places, or to ride in or upon, drive or otherwise operate, any bicycle or other vehicle, in, upon, over or through said streets or other public places or unsupervised places of the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, except for Friday and Saturday nights, when such hours shall be between 12:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, unless such person is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other adult person having the legal care and custody of such minor person, or unless such minor person is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business as directed by his parent, guardian or legal custodian, except as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall prohibit such minor person from attending special and adult-supervised functions conducted by any school, church or fraternal organization which shall continue beyond 11:00 p.m. or 12:30 a.m. as provided above. In all such cases the hours herein prohibited shall be extended one-half hour after the closing of such special function, whichever is the earlier. 
(Ord. No. 1649-78, § 3, 11-6-78)  
Sec. 24-149. - Responsibility of owners of public places. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation operating or having charge of any public place to knowingly permit or suffer the presence of minors under the age of sixteen (16) between the hours of 11:00 p.m. or 12:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, as provided in section 24-148. 
(Ord. No. 1649-78, § 4, 11-6-78)  
Sec. 24-150. - Responsibility of parents. 
It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of sixteen (16) years to permit or by inefficient control to allow such minor person to do any of the things or acts prohibited by section 24-148 between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, except for Friday and Saturday nights, when such hours shall be between 12:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, unless the minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the legal care and custody of the minor, or unless said minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business, directed by his parent, guardian or legal custodian or if the parent, guardian or other adult person herein has made a missing person notification to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 1649-78, § 5, 11-6-78)  
Sec. 24-151. - Notification of parents. 
It is further ordained that no minor person arrested under the provisions of this article shall be placed in confinement until he has been taken home, or the parents, guardian or legal custodian notified, and the arresting officer has ascertained whether or not such minor person is within the control of his parents, guardian or legal custodian; and if such parent, guardian or legal custodian shall state that the minor cannot be controlled by them, then such minor shall be proceeded against, otherwise the parent, guardian or custodian shall be proceeded against. 
(Ord. No. 1649-78, § 6, 11-6-78)  
Sec. 24-152. - Penalties. 
Any minor violating the provisions of section 24-148 shall be dealt with in accordance with the juvenile court law and procedure. Any parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor violating section 24-148 shall, after having been previously notified under section 24-151, be penalized under the provisions of the general penalty section of the Code of Ordinances of the City. 
(Ord. No. 1649-78, § 7, 11-6-78)  
Secs. 24-153, 24-154. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - SEXUAL PREDATOR RESIDENCY RESTRICTIONS 
 
Sec. 24-155. - Findings and intent. 
(a)  The Nebraska Legislature has found that certain sex offenders present a high risk to commit repeat offenses and has enabled municipalities to restrict such persons' place of residency as provided in the Sexual Predator Residency Restriction Act. 
(b)  Sex offenders who prey on children and who are high risks to repeat such acts present an extreme threat to public safety. The cost of sex offender victimization to these children and to society at large, while incalculable, is exorbitant. 
(c)  It is the intent of this article to serve the city's compelling interest to promote, protect and improve the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the City by creating certain areas around locations where children regularly congregate in concentrated numbers where certain sexual predators cannot reside. 
(Ord. No. 2675, § 2, 8-7-06)  
Sec. 24-156. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article: 
(1)  Child care facility means a facility licensed pursuant to the Child Care Licensing Act; 
(2)  School means a public, private, denominational, or parochial school which meets the requirements for state accreditation or approval; 
(3)  Reside means to sleep, live, or dwell at a place, which may include more than one (1) location, and may be mobile or transitory; 
(4)  Residence means a place where an individual sleeps, lives, or dwells, which may include more than one (1) location, and may be mobile or transitory; 
(5)  Sex offender means an individual who has been convicted of a crime listed in R.R.S. § 29-4003 and who is required to register as a sex offender pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration Act; and
