(6)  Sexual predator means an individual who is required to register under the Sex Offender Registration Act, who has committed an aggravated offense as defined in R.R.S. § 29-4001.01, and who has victimized a person eighteen (18) years of age or younger. 
(Ord. No. 2675, § 2, 8-7-06; Ord. No. 2976-16, § 1, 3-7-16)  
Sec. 24-157. - Sexual predator residence restrictions; penalties; exceptions. 
(a)  Prohibited location of residence. It is unlawful for any sexual predator to reside within five hundred (500) feet from a school or child care facility. 
(b)  Measure of distance. For purposes of determining the minimum distance separation, the distance shall be measured by following a straight line from the outer property line of the residence to the nearest outer boundary line of the school or child care facility. 
(c)  Penalties. A person who violates this section shall be punished as provided generally in the Code. 
(d)  Exceptions. This article shall not apply to a sexual predator who: 
(1)  Resides within a prison or correctional or treatment facility operated by the state or a political subdivision; 
(2)  Established a residence before July 1, 2006, and has not moved from that residence; or 
(3)  Established a residence after July 1, 2006, and the school or child care facility triggering the restriction was established after the initial date of the sexual predator's residence at that location. 
(Ord. No. 2675, § 4, 8-7-06)  
Chapter 25 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2537-02, §§ 1—4, adopted Jan. 21, 2002, repealed former sections 25-15—25-22 in their entirety which pertained to the board of park and recreation commissioners and derived from Ord. No. 1916-84, §§ 1—9, adopted Aug. 23, 1984. The editor has renumbered former section 25-23 as 25-2 to consolidate the remaining provisions of this chapter. 
Cross reference— Animals and fowl, Ch. 7; offenses, miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 24; planning, Ch. 27; authority to place traffic-control signs in parks, § 35-200. 
State Law reference— Acquisition of parks, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-695; park fund, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-697; parks and public grounds, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 19-101, 19-102; recreation areas, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-901 et seq. 
 
Sec. 25-1. - Destruction of park property. 
Any person who shall cut down, injure, or destroy any tree, plant, or shrub, or who shall injure or destroy any building, equipment, or paraphernalia belonging to the city, and installed in its parks, or who shall commit any waste of any kind therein, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 10, § 11)  
Sec. 25-2. - Park fund. 
(a)  For the purpose of: 
(1)  Providing funds for amusements and recreations; 
(2)  Providing funds for laying out, purchasing, improving and beautifying parks and public grounds; and 
(3)  Providing for the payment of the salaries or wages of the employees of the park system, the mayor and city commissioners, shall, each year at the time of making the levy for general city purposes, make a levy upon the assessed value of all the taxable property in such city, except intangible property. Such levy shall be collected and paid into the city treasury and shall constitute the parks and recreation fund. 
(b)  All accounts against the parks and recreation fund provided for by subsection (a) of this section for salaries and wages of the employees and all other expenses of such parks and recreation facilities, shall be audited and approved by the commissioner of parks and recreation, and shall then be audited and allowed by the mayor and city commissioners. All warrants drawn on the parks and recreation account shall be paid by the city treasurer from the city general fund. 
(Ord. No. 1916-84, § 9, 8-23-84; Ord. No. 2537-02, § 4, 1-21-02)  
Sec. 25-3. - Parks and recreation advisory committee. 
(a)  Creation and composition. There is hereby created in and for the city a parks/recreation advisory committee to consist of up to twelve (12) persons who are residents of the city. 
(b)  Appointment and terms of members; compensation. Members of the parks/recreation advisory committee shall be selected at the discretion of the parks commissioner. Such members of the committee shall serve until official submission of a letter of resignation to the parks commissioner. All members of the committee shall serve as such without compensation. 
(c)  Organization; quorum, meetings, records. At the first meeting in each year or within a reasonable time thereafter, members of said committee shall meet and elect one (1) of their own members as chairperson. Said committee shall adopt all necessary rules providing for regular and special meetings of said committee and for the conduct of its business. All proceedings shall be well and faithfully set down and preserved in record books which said committee shall provide for that purpose and the records of said committee shall be open to the public as other records of the city. 
(d)  Powers and duties of committee. The primary function of the committee is to assist the parks commissioner and city staff with the continued study and promotion of improvements and additions to the city's park and recreational facilities. The committee may be requested to provide comments on such rules/regulations as may be deemed necessary for the management and care of said parks and the city's recreational facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2574-03, §§ 1—4, 2-17-03; Ord. No. 2866-12, § 1, 2-6-12)  
Chapter 26 - PEDDLERS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
A "peddler" is a person engaged in the selling of personal property by going about from place to place or house to house to sell such property and who carries with him such property for delivery at time of sale, in Nebraska City or any municipally owned or controlled part thereof, and shall also mean and include any person transacting a temporary business within the city at an established business. 
A "solicitor" is a person engaged in going about from place to place or house to house, by newspaper, radio or television advertising, by handbills and circulars or by telephone, soliciting orders for or offering to sell personal property for future delivery in Nebraska City or any municipally owned or controlled part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2136-90, § 1, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 2145-90, § 1, 10-1-90)  
Sec. 26-2. - Exceptions to chapter. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to solicitations, sales or distributions made by charitable, educational or religious organizations which have their principal place of activity in the city. Also excepted are solicitations for the sale of food products from a truck or other vehicle, which product is intended for immediate consumption. 
(Ord. No. 2136-90, § 2, 9-4-90)  
Sec. 26-3. - Refusing to leave. 
Any peddler who enters upon premises owned, leased or rented by another and refuses to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises, or his agent, to leave the same and not return to such premises, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.  
Sec. 26-4. - Entrance to premises restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to enter upon any private premises when the same are posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed" or "No Solicitations Allowed" or other words to such effect.  
Sec. 26-5. - Misrepresentation. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality or nature of his goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the same.  
Sec. 26-6. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to engage in the business of peddling within the city between the hours of one-half (½) hour before sunset and 9:00 a.m. the following morning, or at any time on Sundays, except by specific appointment with or invitation from the prospective customer.  
Sec. 26-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1869-83, adopted Aug. 1, 1983, repealed former § 26-7 which pertained to the use of the telephone and was derived from the original codification.  
Secs. 26-8—26-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Occupation tax, § 34-31 et seq. 
 
Sec. 26-18. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a peddler within this city without first obtaining a permit so to do.  
Sec. 26-19. - Application. 
The application for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall: 
(a)  Contain a statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any state or federal law or municipal ordinance or Code; the nature of the offense; the punishment or penalty assessed therefor, if previously convicted; and the place of conviction. 
(b)  Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment, or deposit, of money in advance of final delivery. 
(c)  The period of time the applicant wishes to engage in business within this city. 
(d)  The local, and permanent, address of the applicant. 
(e)  The local, and permanent, address and the name of the person, if any, that the applicant represents. 
(f)  The kind of goods, wares, merchandise or services the applicant wishes to engage in such business within the city. 
(g)  The last five (5) cities or towns wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city. 
(h)  Such other relevant information as may be required for the investigation of the applicant.  
Sec. 26-20. - Driver's license. 
At the time of filing his application for a permit required by this article, the applicant shall present his driver's license, if he has one, to the chief of police.  
Sec. 26-21. - False information. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading information in connection with his application for a permit required by this article.  
Sec. 26-22. - Fingerprints, photographs. 
At the time of making application for a permit required by this article, the applicant shall submit to fingerprinting and photographing by the chief of police.  
Sec. 26-23. - Fee. 
Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant therefore shall pay a fee, based upon the duration he/she desires to engage in business in the city, as follows: 
(a)  Per day ..... $ 25.00 
(b)  Per week ..... 50.00 
(c)  Per year ..... 200.00 
(Ord. No. 1869-83, § 1, 8-1-83; Ord. No. 2826-10, § 1, 12-20-10)  
Sec. 26-24. - Bond required. 
The application for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall be accompanied by a bond in the penal sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) signed by the applicant and signed, as surety, by some surety company authorized to do business in this state, conditioned for the final delivery of goods, wares, merchandise or services in accordance with the terms of any order obtained prior to delivery and also conditioned to indemnify any and all purchasers or customers for any and all defects in material or workmanship that may exist in the article sold by the principal of such bond, at the time of delivery, and that may be discovered by such purchaser or customer within thirty (30) days after delivery and which bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons that may make any purchase or give any order to the principal on such bond, or to an agent or employee of such principal. 
(Ord. No. 1869-83, § 2, 8-1-83)  
Sec. 26-25. - Service of process. 
Before any permit shall issue under this article, there shall also be filed with the city clerk an instrument in writing, signed by the applicant under oath, nominating and appointing the city clerk his true and lawful agent, with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of such applicant, and service of summons in any action brought upon the applicant's bond shall be deemed made when served on the city clerk.  
Sec. 26-26. - Issuance. 
No permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article until the applicant shall have complied with all the provisions and requirements of this chapter.  
Sec. 26-27. - Limitation. 
No peddler's permit shall be issued to a corporation, partnership or other impersonal legal entity, but each individual person engaging in the business of peddling within the city shall be required to have a permit whether acting for himself or as an agent or representative of another.  
Sec. 26-28. - Contents of permit. 
Each permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be signed by the city clerk, shall be dated as of the date of its issuance, and shall state the duration or term of such permit on the face thereof. Any permit not dated and signed as herein provided, or which was issued in violation of this section, shall be void.  
Sec. 26-29. - Display. 
Every peddler having a permit issued under the provisions of this article and doing business within the city shall display his permit upon the request of any person, and failure so to do shall be deemed a misdemeanor.  
Sec. 26-30. - Duration. 
Every permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for the period of time stated therein, but in no event shall any such permit be issued for a period of time in excess of twelve (12) months.  
Sec. 26-31. - Revocation. 
Any permit issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked for the violation by the permittee of any applicable provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance. Upon such revocation, such permit shall immediately be surrendered to the city clerk, and failure to do so shall be a misdemeanor.  
Chapter 27 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building, Ch. 9; cemeteries, Ch. 10; electricity, Ch. 14; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 15; health and sanitation, Ch. 18; housing, Ch. 19; mobile homes, Ch. 21; parks and recreation, Ch. 25; plumbing and gas, Ch. 28; public works, Ch. 31; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 33; utilities, Ch. 36; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B; signs, § 3-32 et seq. 
State Law reference— City planning, zoning, R.R.S. 1943, § 19-901; urban redevelopment, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-2101 et seq.; municipal planning generally, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1301 et seq.; suburban development, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1716. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 27-1. - Ordinances saved from repeal. 
Nothing contained in this Code of Ordinances, nor in the ordinance adopting this Code, shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect in any manner: 
(a)  Any zoning ordinance, any ordinance amending the text of such zoning ordinance or any ordinance changing the zoning of any property within the city; or 
(b)  Any subdivision ordinance or any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat; 
and all such ordinances are hereby saved from repeal and recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Sec. 27-2. - Extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(a)  All provisions of this Code and city ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to zoning property use, building, electrical work, and plumbing, shall be applicable to the unincorporated area two (2) miles beyond and adjacent to the corporate boundaries of this city with the same force and effect as if such outlying area were within the corporate limits of this city; provided, no such provision or regulation shall be extended or applied so as to prohibit, prevent, or interfere with the conduct of existing farming, livestock operations, businesses, or industry; and provided further, that for purposes of the state power review board, the zoning area of this city shall be one (1) mile beyond and adjacent to the corporate area. The fact that such unincorporated area is located in a different county or counties than some or all portions of the municipality shall not be construed as affecting the powers of the city to apply such provisions or regulations. 
(b)  Such area described in paragraph (a) of this section shall be deemed to be within the district which it adjoins unless it adjoins two (2) or more such districts, in which case the board of adjustment shall determine the district to which it is to belong. 
(Ord. No. 1122, §§ 1, 2, 11-5-62) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-901.  
Sec. 27-3. - Subdivision of existing lots and blocks. 
(a)  The building inspector of the City of Nebraska City is hereby designated as the employee of said city who is authorized to approve, on behalf of such city, further subdivision of existing lots and blocks whenever all required public improvements have been installed, no new dedication of public rights-of-ways or easements is involved, and such subdivision complies with the existing ordinance requirements concerning minimum areas and dimensions of such lots and blocks. 
(b)  A recommendation from the planning commission shall not be required for subdivision of existing lots and blocks whenever all required public improvements have been installed, no new dedication of public rights-of-way or easements is involved, and such subdivision complies with the ordinance requirements concerning minimum areas and dimensions of such lots and blocks. 
(Ord. No. 1874-83, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-83) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1874-83, adopted Sept. 6, 1983, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1 and 2 as § 27-3 was at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 27-4—27-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Municipal planning commission, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1302. 
 
Sec. 27-18. - Created. 
There is hereby created in and for the city a planning commission, which shall be known as the City Planning Commission. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 2)  
Sec. 27-19. - Composition. 
The city planning commission shall consist of nine (9) members, who shall represent in so far as is possible different professions or occupations in the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 3)  
Sec. 27-20. - Appointment. 
The members of the city planning commission shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 3)  
Sec. 27-21. - Terms. 
The term of office of the members of the city planning commission shall be three (3) years; provided, that of the first commission, three (3) members shall be appointed for one (1) year, three (3) members for two (2) years, and three (3) members for three (3) years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 3)  
Sec. 27-22. - Compensation. 
All members of the city planning commission shall serve as such without compensation and shall hold no other municipal office. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 3)  
Sec. 27-23. - Removal of members. 
Any member of the city planning commission may, after a public hearing before the council, be removed from office by the council for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office, or other good and sufficient cause. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 3)  
Sec. 27-24. - Vacancies. 
Vacancies occurring in the membership of the city planning commission, other than by reason of the expiration of terms, shall be filled by the council for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 3)  
Sec. 27-25. - Officers. 
The city planning commission shall elect its chairperson from its members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the chairperson shall be one (1) year, and he or she shall be eligible for reelection. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 4; Ord. No. 2406-97, § 1, 4-7-97)  
Sec. 27-26. - Meetings generally. 
The city planning commission shall hold regular monthly meetings, unless there is no business pending for such monthly meeting, but the commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting in each calendar quarter. The chairperson of the planning commission may also call for a meeting when necessary to deal with business pending before the planning commission. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 4; Ord. No. 2406-97, § 2, 4-7-97)  
Sec. 27-27. - Rules and regulations. 
The city planning commission shall adopt rules and regulations for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 3; Ord. No. 2406-97, § 3, 4-7-97)  
Sec. 27-28. - Records. 
The city planning commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which shall be a public record. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 4; Ord. No. 2406-97, § 4, 4-7-97)  
Sec. 27-29. - Handling of funds. 
The city council may provide the funds, equipment and accommodations necessary for the planning commission's work; but the expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for that purpose by the council. No expenditures from said funds shall be made, except upon claim regularly filed, audited and allowed by the council. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 5)  
Sec. 27-30. - Make, adopt plans. 
It shall be the function and duty of the planning commission to make and adopt plans for the physical development of the city, including any areas outside of its boundaries which, in the commission's judgement, bear relation to the planning of this city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 6)  
Sec. 27-31. - Program recommendations. 
The city planning commission shall, from time to time, recommend to the city council programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 7)  
Sec. 27-32. - Advisory capacity. 
The city planning commission shall consult and advise with the council, other public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civic, educational, professional and other organizations and also with citizens of the city with relation to the protecting or carrying out of the master plan for the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 13, § 7)  
Chapter 28 - PLUMBING AND GAS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 18; housing, Ch. 19; mobile homes, Ch. 21; planning, Ch. 27; utilities, Ch. 36; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference— Plumbing inspection, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1901 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 28-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows: 
Apprentice plumber. Any person who assists or works with or in conjunction with, or under the direct supervision of a master or journeyman plumber. 
Journeyman plumber. A person who performs the manual work of installing plumbing, under the direction of a master plumber, and who holds a journeyman plumber's license, issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
Master plumber. A person who assumes responsible charge and direction of other persons in the installation of plumbing and holds a master plumber's certificate, issued under the provisions of this chapter.  
Sec. 28-2. - Incorporation of state law. 
All provisions required by Chapter 18, Article 19 of the Revised Statutes of Nebraska of 1943, as amended, and as may be amended, are incorporated herein by reference, and shall be part of this chapter in the same manner as though it were set out in full herein.  
Secs. 28-3—28-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLUMBING INSPECTOR 
 
Sec. 28-18. - Office created. 
There is hereby created in and for the city the office of plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 18)  
Sec. 28-19. - Qualifications. 
The plumbing inspector shall have the qualifications of a master plumber and drainlayer, but shall not engage in the business of plumbing or drainlaying during the term of his office. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 18)  
Sec. 28-20. - Appointment. 
The plumbing inspector shall be appointed as other appointive officers of the city are appointed. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 18)  
Sec. 28-21. - Term. 
The term of office of the plumbing inspector shall be for such period of time as may be provided upon his appointment. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 18)  
Sec. 28-22. - Duties. 
The plumbing inspector shall perform such duties as may be directed by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, §§ 16, 19, 20)  
Secs. 28-23—28-32. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LICENSING OF PLUMBERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Occupation taxes, § 34-31 et seq. 
 
Sec. 28-33. - Work to be performed by licensed plumbers. 
It shall be unlawful for any master plumber to have any person other than a licensed master plumber or journeyman plumber to perform any plumbing work. It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector to prefer charges against any person violating the provisions of this section and cause the master plumber who is bonded to be prosecuted. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the employment of common laborers from working in conjunction with and under the direct supervision of the licensed master or journeyman plumbers. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 9)  
Sec. 28-34. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of plumbing or drainlaying as a master or contracting plumber or drainlayer in this city, or to commence or take charge of any work as a master or contracting plumber or drainlayer, unless under special contract with the city, without first having procured from the city a master plumber's and drainlayer's license as required by this article. No such license shall be issued by the city clerk until directed by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 1)  
Sec. 28-35. - Gas installations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than a plumber licensed under the provisions of this article to make any gas installation, alteration or repair work, including the installation of heating equipment and appliances.  
Sec. 28-36. - Application. 
The application for a license required by this article shall be made in writing to the city clerk on forms furnished by him and shall give the full name under which the business is to be conducted. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 2)  
Sec. 28-37. - Application by plumbing contractors. 
Where the applicant for a plumber's license is a plumbing contractor, the applicant shall specify the names of all individuals, qualified as plumbers, who, as employees of such applicant, will install or supervise the installation of any plumbing or drainlaying work for the applicant under the authority of such license. Additional names of qualified individuals may be included in and shown on a license issued pursuant to this section upon payment of an additional fee of two dollars ($2.00) per name. The inclusion of the name of any individual on said license shall not be construed as authority for such individual to install or supervise the installation of any plumbing or drainlaying work otherwise than as an employee of said licensee. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 6)  
Sec. 28-38. - Licensing of firms, corporations, etc. 
In case of a partnership or firm consisting of more than one (1) person, only one (1) of such persons shall be required to qualify as a master plumber. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 4)  
Sec. 28-39. - Examination. 
Before any license required by the provisions of this article may be issued, the application therefor shall be referred to the plumbing inspector and the applicant shall be required to submit to and pass an examination as to his qualifications and fitness, practical and elementary in character, to install plumbing and drainlaying work. Such examination shall be given by the plumbing inspector, who shall have full power and authority to examine applicants and make such rules for its conduct as may be necessary; provided, such rules to be effective shall first be approved by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 2)  
Sec. 28-40. - Temporary license. 
An applicant for a master or a journeyman plumber's license who fails to pass a satisfactory examination conducted by the plumbing inspector may at the discretion of the mayor and city council, be ordered given by the city clerk a temporary permit to work as a plumber for four (4) months. At the end of four (4) months said applicant shall take a second examination, and if he fails this one, he shall receive no further permit to do plumbing. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 8)  
Sec. 28-41. - Fees. 
The following fees shall be charged for the examination of applicants and the issuance of licenses under the provisions of this article: 
(a)  Examination for master plumbers ..... $ 20.00 
(b)  Master plumbers' license, per year ..... 35.00 
Penalty for failure to renew within three (3) months of expiration ..... 5.00 
(c)  Registration of journeyman plumber ..... 5.00 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71; Ord. No. 1837-82, § 5, 11-1-82; Ord. No. 2818-10, § 1, 11-15-10)  
Sec. 28-42. - Payment of fees. 
All examination and renewal or registration fees shall be paid to the city clerk-treasurer, by the applicant before taking the examination for license or before making application for a renewal of his license, as the case may be; and the applicant or the registrant for renewal shall take the clerk-treasurer's receipt for the payment of said fees. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71)  
Sec. 28-43. - Plumber's bond. 
Before any master plumber license is issued, the applicant therefor shall file with the city clerk-treasurer a bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), executed by the applicant and a surety company authorized to do business in this state as surety, running to the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the licensee of all work in full compliance with all provisions of the city Code and any person injured by failure of such licensee to comply with the provisions of the city code shall have a right of action against the licensee and his surety in his name; provided, however, that any person wishing to avail himself of the benefits of the surety bond shall commence action thereof within one (1) year after the date of the completion of the work alleged to have been improperly performed. The bond herein required shall expire on the thirty-first day of December next following its approval by the city council and thereafter by the first day of January of each year a new bond, in form and substance as herein required, shall be given by such person to cover all work he shall perform during such year. Any such bond shall be approved as to form and legal content by the city attorney. A license as hereinabove provided may be issued upon approval of such surety bond, provided the requirements hereof are fulfilled. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 3; Ord. No. 1999-86, § 1, 12-1-86)  
Sec. 28-44. - Issuance. 
Upon the written recommendation of the plumbing inspector that applicant for a license required by this article has shown himself by examination to be competent and qualified to install plumbing and drainlaying work, accompanied by the city clerk-treasurer's receipt for examination and license fee, and upon approval of the required bond by the mayor and city council, the city clerk shall issue and deliver to said applicant a plumber's and drainlayer's license. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71)  
Sec. 28-45. - Record of licenses to be kept. 
The city clerk shall make and keep a record of all licenses issued, lapsed and revoked. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71)  
Sec. 28-46. - Term. 
All licenses issued under this article shall continue in force until January first after the date on which it was granted. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71)  
Sec. 28-47. - Renewal. 
Licenses, at the time of their expiration, may be renewed by the city clerk, upon the written recommendation of the plumbing inspector, without an examination, upon payment of the annual license fee and registration or renewal fee, and upon condition that registrant's bond for the renewal license period is approved and on file. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71)  
Sec. 28-48. - Reexamination upon failure to renew. 
If any license shall be permitted to lapse for a period of more than three (3) months from the date of its expiration, the applicant shall be required to pay the fees as required by this article and to take the initial examination. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71)  
Sec. 28-49. - Licenses not transferable. 
No initial license or renewal license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be transferable. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 5; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 4-13-64; Ord. No. 1338, § 1, 4-19-71)  
Secs. 28-50—28-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 
 
Sec. 28-60. - Permits required. 
No master plumber or drainlayer and no journeyman plumber or drainlayer shall begin any work of plumbing or drainlaying, unless under special contract with the city, until said master plumber or drainlayer in charge of said work shall have secured from the plumbing inspector a special written permit authorizing the said master plumber or drainlayer to do the specific work. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 12; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 2-19-51)  
Sec. 28-61. - When permits not required. 
No special permit shall be required for minor repair work. As used herein minor repair work shall be construed to mean the repairing of leaks in pipes, traps or cocks, opening up waste or supply pipes, traps or drains, or replacing broken fixtures or frozen pipes inside the walls of any building, and where such repair work does not require or include the installation of any waste or supply pipes or new fixtures, and where the location of waste pipes, supply pipes, or fixtures is not changed. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 12; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 2-19-51)  
Sec. 28-62. - Home owner required to obtain permit. 
No home owner doing his own plumbing or drainlaying work shall begin any such work of plumbing or drainlaying until he shall have procured from the plumbing inspector a special written permit authorizing said home owner to do the specific work. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 12; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 2-19-51)  
Sec. 28-63. - Application for permit. 
(a)  All applications for permits required by this article shall be made on forms to be supplied by the city for that purpose in triplicate and the city clerk on receipt of such applications shall deliver one of said copies to the plumbing inspector, one to the applicant or his agent and retain the third copy in his office for filing in the files of the plumbing inspector to be kept therein. 
(b)  Each application for a permit required by this article shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name of the owner, agent or occupant of the premises where the work is to be done; 
(2)  The location of the premises; 
(3)  The name and address of the master plumber or drainlayer having charge of the work; and 
(4)  A full description of the work to be done. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 12; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 2-19-51)  
Sec. 28-64. - Plan of installation required. 
In addition to the requirements of this article, each application for a permit under this article shall be accompanied by a plan of installation which shall be attached to such application and be considered a part thereof. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 13)  
Sec. 28-65. - Issuance. 
The plumbing inspector shall examine each application for a permit required by this article and the plan of installation filed therewith and, if the same complies in all respects with the provisions of this chapter, he shall issue a permit for the installation of the plumbing work. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 13)  
Sec. 28-66. - Display of permit. 
It shall be the duty of each plumber to keep all permits issued under the provisions of this article on the premises where the plumbing work is being done for which such permits were issued until such time as the work is completed, tested and accepted by the plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 10)  
Sec. 28-67. - Notice when work is ready for inspection. 
Upon completion of the installation of any plumbing or drainlaying work, the person performing the work shall notify the plumbing inspector or his deputy, who shall inspect such work and the installation thereof within eight (8) hours of time of notification. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, §§ 12, 14, 15; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 2-19-51)  
Sec. 28-68. - Plan of completed work required. 
Upon the completion of work and prior to inspection as required by this article, the plumber or drainlayer performing the work shall file a completed plan or drawing of said work with the plumbing inspector. Said plan shall show such information as may be required. No certificate of approval may be issued until such plan is filed. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 13)  
Sec. 28-69. - Inspection of work; approval required before use. 
When the plumbing inspector or his deputy shall have inspected all plumbing work and determined that such has been performed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, a certificate of approval shall be issued by the plumbing inspector to the applicant. No plumbing or drainlaying work shall be concealed or used until inspected and approved as required by this section. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, §§ 12, 14, 15; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 2-19-51)  
Sec. 28-70. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2872-12, § 1, adopted March 5, 2012, repealed § 28-70, which pertained to inspection fees and derived from the Code of 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 6, § 21; Ord. No. 1165, adopted April 13, 1964; Ord. No. 1338, adopted April 19, 1971; Ord. No. 1837-82, adopted November 1, 1982 and Ord. No. 2000-86, adopted December 1, 1986.  
Secs. 28-71—28-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - TECHNICAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 28-81. - Plumbing code adopted. 
The city hereby adopts the provisions of the National Standard Plumbing Code, 1993 Edition, as published by the National Association of Plumbing-Heating-Cooling Contractors, the provisions of which are hereby incorporated herein by reference, the same as if set out in full. 
One copy of said code shall be on file with the city clerk-treasurer and be open for inspection and available to the public during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 2046-88, § 1, 5-2-88; Ord. No. 2316-94, § 1, 3-21-94) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2046-88, § 3, adopted May 2, 1988, in part repealed former § 28-81, adopting the 1978 edition of the plumbing code, which provisions derived from Ord. No. 1448-74, § 1, adopted Mar. 4, 1974; Ord. No. 1525-76, § 1, adopted Apr. 19, 1976; Ord. No. 1634-78, § 1, adopted Apr. 17, 1978; Ord. No. 1682-79, § 1, adopted June 4, 1979: and Ord. No. 1812-82, § 1, adopted Apr. 19, 1982. Section 1, Ord. No. 2046-88, enacted new provisions to read as set out in § 28-81. 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt standard codes, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-132; adoption of plumbing code, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1915.  
Sec. 28-82. - Gas code adopted. 
For the purpose of regulating and controlling all gas installations, alterations and repairs made within the city, there is hereby adopted as the gas code in and for the city the "National Fuel Gas Code—An American National Standard," the 1992 Edition, NFPA 54-ANSI Z223.1, recommended by the American Gas Association and the National Fire Protection Association, the provisions of which are hereby incorporated herein by reference the same as if set out in full. 
(Ord. No. 1807-82, § 1, 2-1-82; Ord. No. 2316-94, § 2, 3-21-94)  
Sec. 28-83. - Subsequent editions. 
Subsequent editions or revisions of the codes adopted by the provisions of this article shall be considered adopted and of full force and effect within the city upon the approval thereof by the council and the filing of one (1) copy thereof in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2046-88, § 2, 5-2-88; Ord. No. 2316, § 3, 3-21-94)  
Sec. 28-84. - Conflicts. 
In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the codes adopted by this article and applicable provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation shall prevail and be controlling.  
Sec. 28-85. - Definitions. 
Whenever the word "municipality" or the word "city" is used in the codes adopted by this article it shall be construed to mean the City of Nebraska City, Nebraska. 
Whenever the term "corporate counsel" or "city attorney" is used in the codes adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the city attorney of this city.  
Sec. 28-86. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of the codes adopted by the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished as provided by section 1-8 of this Code. Each day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.  
Chapter 29 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; police department retirement committee, § 2-213; civil service for police officers, § 2-286 et seq.; enforcement of traffic regulations, § 35-22 et seq.; extension of police power, § 1-6. 
 
Sec. 29-1. - Enforcement of law. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and all police officers of the city to enforce the provisions of this Code and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, §§ 7, 8; Ord. No. 2147, § 1, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 29-2. - Arrest generally. 
The chief of police and the members of the police department are empowered to arrest any person for the violation of the provisions of this Code, city ordinances or state laws in the same manner as other law enforcement officers are empowered by state law. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, §§ 7, 8)  
Sec. 29-3. - Assistance. 
Any officer of this city shall have full power and authority to call on any person whenever necessary to assist him in making an arrest, or to take any person before the police judge, or to or from the jail or other place of confinement, and any person who shall fail, neglect or refuse to assist any such officer whenever called upon by him so to do shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof shall be fined in any sum not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, § 9)  
Sec. 29-4. - Special police officers. 
The mayor may, in cases of emergency and when it shall seem necessary for the maintenance of the peace and good order of the city, appoint any number of special police officers who shall serve at his pleasure. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, § 1; Ord. No. 2147-90, § 2, 10-15-90) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-308(4)).  
Sec. 29-5. - Reserved.  
Sec. 29-6. - Failure to make complaint. 
Any police officer who shall wilfully fail, neglect or refuse to make an arrest as empowered by this chapter or who purposely and wilfully fails to make complaint after an arrest is made shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, § 11; Ord. No. 2147-90, § 3, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 29-7. - Sale of unclaimed property. 
All personal property coming into the possession or custody of the police chief, or anyone for him, by virtue of his office, and which shall remain unclaimed for the period of six (6) months after such property came into his possession or custody, or any one for him, shall be sold under his direction at public auction after giving thirty (30) days' notice thereof, by advertisement published once each week for four (4) weeks in the official newspaper of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1565-77, § 1, 1-3-77)  
Sec. 29-8. - Nebraska City Chaplaincy Corps. 
(a)  Creation and purpose. The purpose of the Nebraska City Chaplaincy Corps is to support the mission and goals of the Nebraska City Police and Fire/Rescue Departments as well as the Otoe County Sheriff's Office by, upon request, providing volunteer spiritual guidance, counseling, and comfort to emergency personnel and/or their families while additionally serving as a resource to the community in times of personal family crisis. Chaplains will also volunteer during disasters as requested by the appropriate emergency management agency. 
(b)  Board of directors; composition. There is hereby created in and for the city the Nebraska City Chaplaincy Corps. The corps shall have a governing body known as the board of directors. The board of directors shall consist of seven (7) persons and be comprised of the following positions: 
(1)  Lead chaplain (elected by majority vote of the board); 
(2)  Nebraska City Chief of Police or his/her Nebraska City Police Department designee; 
(3)  Nebraska City Fire and Rescue Chief or his/her Nebraska City Fire and Rescue designee; 
(4)  Full-time Nebraska City Fire and Rescue Department employee designated by the Nebraska City Fire and Rescue Chief; 
(5)  Otoe County Sheriff or his/her Otoe County Sheriff's Office designee; 
(6)  Nebraska City Ministerial Association Chair so long as he/she is a chaplain in this chaplaincy corps or his/her designee of a chaplaincy corps chaplain; 
(7)  Chaplaincy corps chaplain designated by the Nebraska City Ministerial Association Chair. 
(c)  Appointment and terms of members; compensation. Members of the board of directors shall be annually designated at the first meeting in each calendar year or within a reasonable time thereafter. Such directors shall serve at the discretion of the designating official and may be removed for any or no reason by the designating official. All members of the committee shall serve as such without compensation. 
(d)  Organization, meetings, records. At the first meeting in each year or within a reasonable time thereafter, shall elect a chairperson, vice-chairperson, lead chaplain, and such other persons as may be necessary to carry out the board duties, and shall review and adopt all necessary rules providing for regular and special meetings of said board and for the conduct of its business. All proceedings shall be well and faithfully set down and preserved in record books which said board shall provide for that purpose and the records of said board shall be open to the public. 
(e)  Powers and duties of board of directors. The primary function of the board of directors is to govern the chaplaincy corps. The board shall adopt such rules/regulations as may be deemed necessary for the corps not inconsistent with this section. 
(Ord. No. 2990-17, § 1, 5-15-17)  
Chapter 31 - PUBLIC WORKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Expenditures for public works, § 2-253; building, Ch. 9; electricity, Ch. 14; health and sanitation, Ch. 18; housing, Ch. 19; planning, Ch. 27; plumbing and gas, Ch. 28; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 33; utilities, Ch. 36; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 31-1. - Participation in pension plan. 
The board of public works is hereby authorized to cooperate and participate in the pension plan on file in the office of the city clerk, and intended for the benefit of the employees of the board of public works, and for the purpose of such pension pian, the board of public works may make contributions equal to employee contributions under such plan, authorize deductions from salaries of employees and take such other steps as may be necessary and are consistent with said plan. 
(Ord. No. 1285, § 1, 4-21-69)  
Sec. 31-2. - Group insurance. 
The board of public works is hereby authorized to participate in a group insurance plan for the benefit of its employees covering sickness, accident, and life insurance.  
Secs. 31-3—31-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— City attorney to represent board, § 2-189. 
 
Sec. 31-18. - Created. 
A board of public works for the city is hereby created, and shall be known and designated as "The Nebraska City Board of Public Works." 
(Ord. No. 800, § 1, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 823, § 1, 10-1-45)  
Sec 31-19. - Composition. 
The board of public works shall consist of five (5) members. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 1, 5-1-44)  
Sec. 31-20. - Appointment. 
The mayor shall appoint, subject to the approval of the council or a majority thereof, the five (5) members of the board of public works, who shall be citizens and bona fide residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 1, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 823, § 1, 10-1-46)  
Sec 31-21. - Terms. 
Each member of the board of public works shall serve for a term of five (5) years and until his successor is appointed and qualified; provided that the members of the original board shall be known and designated as "The Nebraska City Board of Public Works, and shall be appointed in such manner that the terms of one member shall expire each year. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 1, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 823, § 1, 10-1-45)  
Sec. 31-22. - Filling of vacancies. 
Vacancies occurring in the membership of the board of public works shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 1, 5-1-44)  
Sec. 31-23. - Oath required, conflict of interest. 
Each of the members of the board of public works shall, before entering upon the discharge of his or her duties, take an oath to discharge faithfully the duties of his or her office. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 2, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 1879-83, § 1, 10-17-83)  
Sec. 31-24. - Salaries. 
No member of the board of public works shall receive any salary or compensation for his services as a member of such board, but the actual and necessary expenses incurred by said board in the performance of their duties shall be allowed and paid as a part of the cost of operation and maintenance of said public utilities from the same sources and in like manner as other costs of operation and maintenance are paid. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 5, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 1, 2-5-62) 
State Law reference— Salary of members of board of public works limited, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-325(2).  
Sec. 31-25. - Rules, regulations. 
The board of public works is hereby empowered to adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary for its government and the transaction of business, and to provide for amendment thereof. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 3, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45)  
Sec. 31-26. - Other officers, etc. 
The board of public works shall select from its membership a chairman and a secretary and may select such other officers, clerks, deputies, laborers and other help and assistants as may be deemed by such board to be necessary or expedient. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 3, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 3, 2-5-62)  
Sec. 31-27. - Bond of employees. 
The board of public works shall require of such of its members, clerks, assistants and employees as required by law or as such board shall deem necessary or proper a bond of such character and amount as shall be determined by the board, and said bonds, where required by the board, shall be approved by the board and filed with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 4, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 4, 2-5-62)  
Sec. 31-28. - Management of systems. 
The board of public works is hereby empowered to perform the following duties: 
(a)  Operate, manage and maintain the city electric, natural gas, water works and sanitary sewerage systems and any and all property owned by the city and used in connection with the operation and maintenance of such public utilities, including the erection and construction of additions, extensions and improvements in and to such systems. 
(b)  Purchase all materials and supplies for the operation and maintenance of such utility systems. 
(c)  Collect all rates, charges, revenues and profits accruing on account of the ownership and operation of such utility systems. 
(d)  Keep the accounts of cash received and disbursed on account of the operation and maintenance of such utility systems and of all amounts receivable and payable on account thereof. 
(e)  Cause the public utilities to be audited separately from the other functions of the city on an accrual basis and containing statements and materials conforming to generally accepted accounting principles. Said audit shall be completed and an annual audit report submitted within six (6) months after the close of the fiscal year, unless an extension of time shall be granted by written resolution adopted by the city council. Such separate audit and conforming annual audit report may be by a different accountant than the one (1) making the city's general audit. 
(f)  Perform such other acts as the board may deem expedient in the operation, maintenance and conduct of such utility systems and the business and services incident thereto. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 4, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 2, 2-5-62; Ord. No. 2936-14, § 1, 6-2-14)  
Sec. 31-29. - Application of bond ordinances. 
The management, operation and maintenance of the public utility systems and of the property used in connection therewith shall at all times be in conformity with the provisions of all bond ordinances applicable thereto and the refunding revenue bonds of the city issued pursuant thereto, and in conformity with the provisions of any ordinance pertaining to the refunding of such outstanding bonds, or the issuance of new or additional bonds secured by the revenues of said properties. If at any time the provisions of this article shall appear to conflict in any manner with the provisions of such bond ordinances or of the bonds issued pursuant thereto or with the provisions of any ordinance pertaining to the refunding of said bonds or issuance of new or additional revenue bonds secured by the revenues of said properties, then the provisions of such bond ordinances and of the bonds issued pursuant thereto and the provisions of any ordinance pertaining to the refunding of outstanding bonds or issuance of new or additional bonds secured by the revenues of said properties shall prevail over the provisions of this article and the provisions of this article shall yield thereto to the extent necessary to reconcile any such conflicting provisions. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 7, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 879, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45)  
Sec. 31-30. - Deposits into funds. 
All moneys received by the board of public works or its employees arising from the ownership and operation of the public utility systems shall be promptly paid over to the city clerk-treasurer, and the amounts so received shall be kept in a separate fund designated as the "combined utilities fund." 
(Ord. No. 800, § 6, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 2, 2-5-62; Ord. No. 1881-83, § 1, 11-7-83)  
Sec. 31-31. - Disbursements of funds—Generally. 
All claims against the funds of the board of public works, except claims against the "operation and maintenance account", shall be filed with the city clerk-treasurer, and all disbursements from such funds, except disbursements from the "operation and maintenance account", shall be by warrants upon claims so filed and allowed by the council in the manner provided by law, after first having been examined and approved by the board. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 6, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 1, 2-5-62)  
Sec. 31-32. - Same—For operation, maintenance. 
The board of public works shall draw its orders on the "operation and maintenance account" in the hands of the city clerk-treasurer to the credit of the public utility systems in payment of salaries, labor, insurance premiums, materials and supplies, and such other expenses incident to the operation and conduct of such utility systems as the board shall deem expedient in its management, operation and maintenance of such systems, all for and on behalf of the city as the owner of such property. Such orders shall be signed by two (2) members of the board and paid by the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 4, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 1, 2-5-62)  
Sec. 31-33. - Monthly reports. 
The board of public works shall cause monthly reports to be made to the city council each month of all receipts and expenses from the operation of each public utility system under its management. 
(Ord. No. 800, § 4, 5-1-44; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 8-6-45; Ord. No. 823, § 2, 10-1-45; Ord. No. 1109, § 1, 2-5-62)  
Sec. 31-34. - Expenditures restricted. 
The board of public works is hereby given authority, in addition to authority given in other ordinances or sections hereof, to spend any amount, not to exceed seven thousand, five hundred dollars ($7,500.00), in the operation and management of the public utilities without authorization from the city council; and it shall further have authority to spend any amount not to exceed seven thousand, five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) for the improvement, construction or extension of any of the public utilities. 
(Ord. No. 1888-83, § 1, 11-21-83)  
Sec. 31-35. - Estimates. 
Upon request of the mayor and city council, the city engineer shall make estimates of the cost of labor and material which may be done or furnished by contract with the city.  
Sec. 31-36. - Authorization for contracts. 
All contracts made by the board of public works for extensions to water and electric lines or improvements to said services, shall be authorized by the board of public works by appropriate action, and the record of all actions by said board shall be spread in full upon the minute record of board proceedings.  
Sec. 31-37. - Transfer of funds. 
That commencing on the first day of September, 2011, and quarterly thereafter, the City of Nebraska City shall transfer from their combined utilities fund to the general fund of the City of Nebraska City, five (5) percent of the gross revenues received from the electric energy and natural gas sales from customers residing within the corporate limits of Nebraska City and within the two mile zoning jurisdiction of the City of Nebraska City. Such funds shall be transferred within thirty (30) days of the end of each calendar quarter. 
(Ord. No. 2715-08, 1-21-08; Ord. No. 2849-11, § 1, 5-2-11)  
Chapter 32 - RAILROADS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Regulation of railroads, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 16-211, 16-212. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Obstructing streets. 
It is hereby declared unlawful for any railroad company operating a railroad into or through city to obstruct any of the public streets within city by leaving trains or cars standing thereon so as to prevent the public from crossing said railroad track or tracks, for a longer period at one time than five (5) minutes except in cases of inevitable accident. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 1)  
Sec. 32-2. - Crossing lights. 
At all points within the city where any railroad or railway track shall intersect any street, there shall be installed and maintained, when ordered by the motion or resolution of the mayor and council, wholly at the expense of such railroad company maintaining said intersecting railroad or railway, an electric light of at least such power and strength as is commonly used by this city for its street lighting, which electric light shall be kept lighted at all times between one (1) hour after sunset in the evening and one (1) hour before sunrise in the morning following. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 4)  
Sec. 32-3. - Warning devices. 
When ordered by the mayor and council, approved automatic lights or signals shall be installed at designated crossings. Said automatic lights and signals shall be kept in good working order at all hours of the day or night so that all persons approaching said crossings will be warned of the danger of approaching trains, engines or cars on the tracks of said company. Likewise, the mayor and council may order railroad companies to maintain gates at designated crossings. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 5)  
Sec. 32-4. - Speed. 
No railway train, railway engine, railway car, railway motor or railway truck shall be operated over any railroad within the city at a greater rate of speed than fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 10; Ord. No. 806, § 1, 2-5-45)  
Sec. 32-5. - Loitering about tracks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter about any railroad track. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(f), § 9)  
Sec. 32-6. - Boarding, alighting from train restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be jumping off or on any railroad train or car while the same is at rest or in motion; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to apply to any employee of the railroad or to any person authorized to use the same. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(g), § 9)  
Sec. 32-7. - Bell and whistle regulations. 
There shall be a bell or gong and whistle attached to every locomotive, engine or motor operated within this city. The bell or gong shall be rung continuously by the engineer or fireman in charge of the locomotive, engine or motor while passing over any railroad line within the city. The whistle shall be blown by the engineer or fireman in charge of such locomotive, engine or motor before crossing any street within the city. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 6)  
Sec. 32-8. - Draining right-of-way. 
It shall be the duty of any railroad company owning, maintaining or operating a railroad within or through the city to construct and keep in repair ditches, drains and culverts along, under and adjacent to its railroad tracks at all places within the city and on its own right-of-way, where the same may be necessary for the escape of water and the proper drainage of the territory on either side of said railroads. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 8)  
Sec. 32-9. - Failure to drain. 
When any drains, ditches or culverts along or within a railroad company's right-of-way may be necessary for the escape of water and the proper drainage of the territory on either side of any railroad track, the mayor and council, upon recommendation of the superintendent of the department of streets, public improvements and public property, may, by resolution, call upon the proper railroad company to construct or repair such drain, ditch or culvert and to place the same in a proper condition for the escape of water for the proper drainage of the territory on either side of said railroads. A copy of every such resolution shall be served upon the local agent of the railroad company whose duty it is to construct or keep in repair any such drain, ditch or culvert. For a failure or refusal to comply with any such resolution within fourteen (14) days after the service thereof as aforesaid, such railroad company, its local agent, section foreman or the employee in charge of the maintenance and way through said city, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 9)  
Sec. 32-10. - Railroad companies; obstructing view at crossings prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to obstruct or obscure the traveling public's view by storing or parking any railroad car on a railroad track within two hundred (200) feet of the crossing of any such railroad track and a public road within the corporate limits of the municipality; provided, however, in no instance shall any person who is authorized to control the movement of such railroad car or cars within such distance be prevented from reasonably conducting his or her business. 
(Ord. No. 1974-86, § 1, 5-19-86) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 74-1323.  
Secs. 32-11—32-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CROSSING MAINTENANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Construction and improvements of streets and sidewalks generally, § 33-18 et seq. 
 
Sec. 32-20. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article, the word "crossing" shall means all places within the city within the railroad's right-of-way where the public streets or alleys intersect and cross any tracks of such railroad, and shall include viaducts and roadways under or over such railroad tracks. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 2)  
Sec. 32-21. - Duty to maintain. 
It shall be the duty of all railroad companies owning, operating and maintaining a railroad passing through this city to place, keep or maintain crossings, and all other places within their right-of-way where the public streets or alleys of the city intersect and cross any of said railroad tracks, in a suitable and safe condition for public travel over and across the same. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 2)  
Sec. 32-22. - Notice to repair, replace. 
If any crossing shall be at any time in bad condition or unsafe or inconvenient for public travel, the mayor and council, upon recommendation of the superintendent of the department of streets, public improvements and public property, may, by resolution, call upon the proper railroad company to repair or replace said crossing and render the same safe and convenient for public travel. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 3)  
Sec. 32-23. - Specifications for replacements. 
Unless otherwise ordered by the city council, all railroad crossing replacements shall be made with steel rails or steel plates. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 3)  
Sec. 32-24. - Service of notice. 
A copy of every resolution or notice issued under the provisions of this article shall be served upon the local agent of the railroad company whose duty it is to maintain the crossing determined to be unsafe. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 3)  
Sec. 32-25. - Failure to comply. 
If any resolution or notice issued under the provisions of this article shall not be complied with by the railroad company upon which the same was served within thirty (30) days after such service, such railroad company shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided for violations of this Code. Each day after such thirty (30) days has elapsed shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 5, Art. 7, § 3)  
Chapter 33 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Planning, Ch. 27; public works, Ch. 31; utilities, Ch. 36; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference— Construction and maintenance of streets, sidewalks, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 16-249, 16-250; street improvements generally, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 16-601 et seq., 18-2001 et seq.; street commissioner's duties, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-324. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 33-1. - Additional parking. 
The mayor and council may by ordinance or resolution order or permit the parking or improvement for lawn, flowers or shrubbery of any other or further portions of any street or avenue in the city, which shall not be, in their judgment, necessarily required for actual travel, and when so parked, planted or improved, it shall be unlawful for any person to lead, ride or drive any animal or vehicle upon the portion of said street so parked or improved. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 1, § 3)  
Sec. 33-2. - Driving over newly laid pavement. 
No person shall ride or drive any horse or vehicle over or across any pavement newly laid or repaired, across or around which there has been placed a barricade, or at or near which there is a person or sign warning persons against riding or driving over such pavement. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 1, § 7)  
Sec. 33-3. - Harmful liquids prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or permit to leak in the gutter or upon any asphalt street in the city any waste gasoline, kerosene, high lubricating oils or other liquids which are a solvent for asphalt. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 1(a), § 5)  
Sec. 33-4. - Driving stakes in pavement. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any peg or stake of any kind into the pavement in any street or alley of the city without the consent of the city engineer or street foreman. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 1(a), § 11)  
Sec. 33-5. - Street foreman—duties generally. 
The street foreman shall be subject to the orders of the superintendent and, under said superintendent's supervision, shall have general charge, direction and control of all work on the streets, sidewalks, culverts and bridges of the city. The street foreman shall also perform such other duties as the city council may require. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, § 4)  
Sec. 33-6. - Same—duties as sidewalk inspector. 
(a)  As sidewalk inspector, the street foreman shall have general control of all sidewalk and sidewalk spaces in the city. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the street foreman, as sidewalk inspector, to: 
(1)  See that sidewalk and sidewalk spaces are not unlawfully occupied; 
(2)  Report all obstructions on sidewalks and unlawful uses of the same to the superintendent; 
(3)  Issue all notices pertaining to sidewalks, crossings and alleys; 
(4)  Keep in a suitable book an accurate record of each notice served pursuant to this section with the time and manner of such service; and 
(5)  Keep a record of all sidewalks ordered built. 
(c)  For the purposes of performing the duties required by this section, the street foreman shall have the authority to go upon any private property and to enter any areaways under the sidewalks at reasonable hours. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 6, Art. 3, § 4)  
Sec. 33-7. - Barbed wire fence. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct or maintain within the city an outside barbed wire fence; provided this section shall not apply to protective fences on which the barbed wire is not nearer the ground than five (5) feet. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 11, Art. 5(j), § 1)  
Sec. 33-8. - Fees for vacating or closing; disposition of funds. 
The city clerk shall at the time of receiving a request for the vacating or closing of a street or alley, charge and collect the following fees: 
Street closing or vacating ..... $30.00 
plus any charges incurred in public notices, surveys, postings or other legal charges. 
Alley closing ..... 30.00 
plus any charges incurred in public notices, surveys, postings or other legal charges. 
Said fees are to be paid even though the request is not granted by the council. All fees collected under the provisions of this article are to be credited to the general fund of the city and shall be used to defray the cost of expenses of administering this article and thereafter for general purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1434-73, § 1, 11-5-73)  
Secs. 33-9—33-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND IMPROVEMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Maintenance of railroad crossings, § 32-20 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 33-18. - Grades established; standards adopted by reference. 
Every grade hereafter fixed upon any street, alley, sidewalk, gutter or for any other purpose within this city shall be fixed and established with relation to bench marks and elevations contained in the Grade Book, prepared by the City Engineer, a copy of which is now in the custody of the city clerk; and said Grade Book, together with such further elevations as may be ordained by the mayor and council from time to time are hereby incorporated by reference into this section the same as though copied at full length herein. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 1 (b), § 1)  
Sec. 33-19. - Plans, specifications generally. 
All streets, sidewalks and other public ways constructed, reconstructed or repaired within this city shall conform to such plans and specifications as may be prepared by the city engineer and adopted by the mayor and city council and on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 6)  
Secs. 33-20—33-22. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SIDEWALKS AND CURBING 
 
Sec. 33-23. - Permit to construct or repair sidewalks or curbing—Required. 
Any person desiring to construct, or cause to be reconstructed or repaired any curbing or sidewalk on any street or avenue abutting his or her property in the City of Nebraska City shall obtain a permit as hereinafter provided; and it shall be unlawful for any person to construct any curbing or sidewalk without first having obtained said permit. Application for said permit shall be made in writing, filed with the office of the office of the city clerk and shall give a description of the lot or piece of land along which it is desired to construct said curbing or sidewalk. Said application shall be approved by the engineer for the city or the street commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 1545-76, § 2, 8-2-76) 
Editor's note— Pursuant to § 1 of Ord. No. 1545-76, enacted Aug. 2, 1976, §§ 2 and 3 thereof have been added as §§ 33-23 and 33-24 at the editor's discretion. 
For the most recent policy of the city regarding constructing, reconstructing and repairing sidewalks, see Res. No. 2035, passed Nov. 15, 1999, on file in the clerk's office.  
Sec. 33-24. - Same—Fee; disposition of funds. 
The city clerk-treasurer shall at the time each person makes application to construct, reconstruct or repair any curbing or sidewalk, charge and collect in advance of issuance of said permit, a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
All fees collected under the provisions of this division are hereby declared to be occupation tax money levied for revenue purposes; shall be credited to the general fund of the city and shall be used to defray the cost of expenses of administering this article and thereafter for general purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1545-76, § 3, 8-2-76; Ord. No. 2779-09, § 1, 9-21-09) 
Note— See editor's note, § 33-23.  
Sec. 33-25. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean that concrete or hard surface area intended for pedestrian use and located between the curb line and the adjacent property line. 
Superintendent. The superintendent of the department of streets, public improvements and public property. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 13)  
Sec. 33-26. - Petition for sidewalks. 
Upon the petition of any freeholder, the mayor and city council may order permanent sidewalks built in accordance with this division, upon the freeholder making, executing and delivering to the city an agreement to pay for the same and that the cost of the same, until paid, shall be a perpetual lien upon the real estate along which the freeholder desires such sidewalk to be constructed, and giving and granting to the city the right to assess and levy the costs of the same against the real estate and promising to pay the same with interest. The total cost of such improvement shall be levied, allocated, financed, and specially assessed as provided by law. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 7)  
Sec. 33-27. - Owner to construct sidewalks; notice to be given. 
Whenever the mayor and council shall deem it necessary that a sidewalk be constructed or reconstructed in front of any lot or piece of ground in the city, they shall so order and the street foreman, under the direction of the superintendent shall thereupon notify in writing the owner of such lot or piece of ground of the work or improvement to be done, and such owner so notified shall be allowed thirty (30) days from the service of said notice in which to construct or reconstruct the same. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, §§ 2, 4)  
Sec. 33-28. - Duty of adjoining owner to maintain. 
Every owner of any lot or lots, or pieces of land within the limits of this city shall at all times keep and maintain the sidewalk along and contiguous to said lot, lots or pieces of land, as the case may be, in good and proper repair, and in a condition reasonably safe for travel for all travelers thereon. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 1)  
Sec. 33-29. - Liability for failure to maintain. 
In the event any owner or owners of any lot, lots, or lands, abutting on any street or avenue or part thereof, shall fail to construct or repair any sidewalk in front of his lot, lots or lands within the time and in the manner as directed and required by this division after having received due notice to do so, he shall be liable for all damages or injury occasioned by reason of the defective or dangerous condition of any sidewalk, and the mayor and city council shall have power to cause such sidewalk to be constructed or repaired and assess the costs thereof against such property. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 1)  
Sec. 33-30. - Service of notice. 
(a)  Residents. The notice required by section 33-27 shall be given by delivering the same to the owner in person or by leaving it at his usual place of residence in the city. 
(b)  Nonresidents. If the owner is a nonresident of the city, notice may be given by publication one (1) time in a legal newspaper published in and of general circulation in the city. 
(c)  Contents. The notice shall notify such owner of the passage of said resolution and that he will have thirty (30) days from and after the service of notice, or from the day of publication within which to construct or reconstruct the sidewalk so ordered or cause the same to be done. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 2)  
Sec. 33-31. - Construction or reconstruction by city. 
If an owner fails to construct or reconstruct a sidewalk or cause the same to be done as required by this division within thirty (30) days after notice being given as provided by this division then and in that case, the city will cause said sidewalk to be constructed and the cost will be levied and assessed thereafter by the mayor and city council as a special tax against said premises. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, §§ 2, 5)  
Sec. 33-32. - Assessment of city's costs. 
In the event the city shall construct or reconstruct a sidewalk after the owner has been notified as required by this division and has failed or refused to perform the work the costs incurred by the city will be levied and assessed as a special tax against said premises. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 2)  
Sec. 33-33. - Sidewalk repairs; notice; period for compliance. 
(a)  Whenever the superintendent shall deem it necessary that any sidewalk shall be repaired, or it shall be required by the mayor and council, the superintendent shall notify or cause his street foreman to notify the owner of the lot or piece of land along and contiguous to which such sidewalk is situated, to repair the same within seven (7) days from and after the giving of notice. 
(b)  Oral notice to the owner shall be deemed sufficient. If the owner is not found by the superintendent or his street foreman, then a written notice left in the house situated on such lot or piece of ground, or posted upon said premises, shall be sufficient, and the seven (7) days shall begin to run from the leaving or posting up of such notice, as the case may be. 
(Code 1938, Ch. 13, Art. 2, § 3; Ord. No. 1414-73, § 1, 8-20-73)  
Secs. 33-34—33-43. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS AND CUTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Regulation of excavations, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-232. 
 
Sec. 33-44. - Permit required.
